Create a cylindrical pin with a diameter of 10mm and a length of 80mm. One end should have a hemispherical dome. The other end should have a 45-degree chamfer of 1mm. This pin is designed to fit snugly into corresponding holes.

Design a two-part enclosure (base and lid) for a small electronic device. The overall external dimensions of the assembled enclosure are 120mm x 80mm x 40mm. The wall thickness for both parts is 2mm. The base should have four internal bosses for M3 screws (3mm diameter, 5mm height) at the corners, 10mm from the edges. The lid should have corresponding holes. Add a rectangular cutout for a display (50x30mm) on the top face of the lid, centered. Include two simple snap-fit clips on each long side of the lid to engage with slots in the base. Spatial accuracy of 0.1mm is required for mating features.

Generate a helical compression spring. The wire diameter is 2mm. The mean coil diameter is 15mm. It should have 8 active coils, with a pitch of 5mm. The ends should be closed and ground flat, meaning the last 0.75 turns at each end are flattened against the adjacent coil. The total free length will depend on these parameters.

Model a single-start worm gear thread profile on a cylindrical shaft. The shaft diameter is 30mm and length 100mm. The module is 2.5mm, and the pressure angle is 20 degrees. The thread should run for 80mm of the shaft's length. The profile requires accurate representation of the involute form for the worm.

Create a parametric V-block clamp assembly. The main V-block has a 90-degree V-groove. It should be 100mm long, 50mm wide, and 60mm tall. A separate clamping block, 50mm long and 20mm wide, slides vertically above the V-groove. A threaded rod (M10, 100mm long) passes through the clamp block and is held by a simple nut on top. The rod should be centered horizontally above the V-groove. The V-block and clamp block should be aluminum, and the rod/nut steel.

Design an intricate ventilation grille. It consists of a rectangular frame (200mm x 100mm, 10mm thick, 5mm wall thickness) and an array of 10 airfoil-shaped slats inside. Each slat should have a chord length of 80mm and a maximum thickness of 5mm, with a specific NACA 4-digit airfoil profile (e.g., NACA 0012). The slats should be angled at 30 degrees relative to the grille's main plane and evenly spaced within the frame. The spatial accuracy for the airfoil profile should be high.

Model an ergonomic handle grip. The grip should be 120mm long with a varying cross-section designed to fit a hand comfortably. Start with a circular base of 30mm diameter, transition to an oval cross-section of roughly 35mm x 25mm in the middle, and taper back to a 25mm circle at the end. Use splines or complex lofting/sweeping to achieve a smooth, organic shape with finger grooves. Include a 20mm deep, 10mm diameter mounting bore at one end.

Create a threaded bottle neck and a matching cap. The bottle neck should have an outer diameter of 30mm, an inner diameter of 25mm, and be 20mm tall. It requires an external metric thread M28x1.5 (28mm major diameter, 1.5mm pitch, 60-degree profile). The cap should be a cylinder with a knurled outer surface (diameter 32mm, height 15mm) and an internal M28x1.5 thread, designed to mate perfectly with the bottle neck. Both parts should have 0.05mm tolerance for threads.

Design a simple interlocking dovetail puzzle piece. The main body is a 50mm cube. One face should have a male dovetail profile (30mm wide at base, 20mm wide at top, 10mm deep, 45-degree angle). The opposite face should have a matching female dovetail cutout. Other faces can have partial dovetails or other simple interlocking features to create a complex assembly possibility. Precision is key for interlocking.

Generate a multi-faceted light reflector. The base is a 100mm diameter, 5mm thick circular plate. On this plate, create an array of 25 small (e.g., 10mm diameter) parabolic or conical indentations, arranged in a grid or circular pattern, each designed to reflect light. The depth of each indentation should be 5mm. The surface finish of the indentations should be highly reflective.

Model a small gear pump housing. The housing is a rectangular block 80mm x 60mm x 30mm. It needs two cylindrical internal cavities (diameter 25mm, depth 25mm) that overlap slightly (overlap distance 2mm) to form a figure-eight cross-section, where two spur gears would mesh. Include inlet and outlet ports (10mm diameter) tangent to these cavities, ensuring smooth internal flow paths. Add mounting holes and a cover plate (separate part) with gaskets implied.

Design a full planetary gear set assembly. Include a sun gear (20 teeth), three planet gears (10 teeth each), and a ring gear (40 teeth, internal teeth). All gears must use a 20-degree pressure angle and a module of 2mm. Create a simple planet carrier that holds the planet gears around the sun gear. Ensure all gears mesh correctly without interference. This involves precise tooth profile generation for both external and internal teeth, and accurate positioning of all components. Visual appearance: gears in distinct metallic colors, carrier in a contrasting material.

Create a single turbine blade with complex geometry. The blade has an overall length of 150mm. Its cross-section should be a complex aerodynamic airfoil profile that changes both shape and twist angle along its length (e.g., 0 degrees twist at the root, 20 degrees at the tip). The root of the blade should feature a 'fir-tree' or 'dovetail' attachment profile for mounting into a turbine disc, requiring extreme geometric accuracy for stress distribution. The surface should be extremely smooth and precise.

Model a parametric cam and follower mechanism. The cam is a disk with a diameter of 100mm and a thickness of 10mm. It should feature a specific lift profile (e.g., simple harmonic motion, cycloidal) for a full 360-degree rotation, lifting the follower by 20mm. The follower is a roller type (20mm diameter) that maintains continuous contact with the cam profile. Design a simple base block with a pivot for the follower arm and a central shaft for the cam. The entire mechanism must animate conceptually, showing proper follower tracking.

Design a complex fluid flow manifold. The manifold has three inlet pipes (20mm internal diameter) that merge smoothly into a single outlet pipe (35mm internal diameter). The internal channels must be highly optimized for fluid flow, meaning no sharp corners, complex internal fillets, and potentially non-circular transitions. The outer body of the manifold should be compact and robust. This requires advanced blending and surface generation techniques to ensure smooth internal geometry.

Develop an articulated robot arm joint assembly. This joint connects two arm segments and allows for rotation. It should include: two main housing parts (one for each arm segment), integrated bearing seats for two large angular contact bearings (ID 30mm, OD 50mm, width 12mm), a central shaft that locks the two housings together but allows relative rotation, internal channels for routing motor cables, and precise mating features (e.g., bolt patterns, alignment pins) for connecting to the arm segments. High precision (0.02mm) is crucial for bearing fits and mating surfaces.

Create an automotive wheel hub assembly. This includes the main hub body, integrated bearing races (inner and outer), mounting points for a brake rotor (e.g., 5 bolt holes on a 114.3mm bolt circle diameter for a 5x114.3 pattern), and five wheel stud holes (M12 threaded holes) on a 114.3mm bolt circle. The hub should also feature a central bore for the axle shaft and detailed features for dust seals. Material is cast iron. Dimensions and spatial relationships must be extremely accurate to automotive standards.

Design a shaft with external involute splines and a matching hub with internal involute splines. Both components should have 16 teeth, a 30-degree pressure angle, and a module of 1.5mm. The splines must be precisely generated to ensure a tight fit (H7/h6 tolerance implied). The shaft length is 100mm, with splines running for 50mm. The hub is 40mm long. This requires accurate programmatic generation of the involute profile.

Generate a complex, lightweight support structure using a lattice or Voronoi pattern. Start with a solid block (e.g., 100mm x 100mm x 50mm). Within this block, create an internal cellular structure (e.g., a gyroid infill, or a randomized Voronoi pattern of struts with a minimum strut thickness of 1.5mm) that provides structural support while minimizing material. The outer surfaces should remain solid, encasing the lattice. This requires advanced algorithmic geometry generation.

Model one half of a continuously variable transmission (CVT) pulley. This half-pulley is conical in shape, with a large diameter of 150mm and a small diameter of 80mm, over an axial length of 60mm. The conical surface must be perfectly smooth and precise (surface finish Ra 0.8um implied). It needs complex internal features for mounting onto a shaft, potentially involving splines or keyways, and integrated balancing features. The material is hardened steel.

Design a custom heat sink with optimized fin geometry. The base plate is 100mm x 100mm x 5mm. On this base, create an array of 20 fins. Instead of simple rectangular fins, these fins should have a tapered or wavy profile, potentially varying in height (e.g., 20mm to 30mm) and thickness (e.g., 1mm to 0.5mm) along their length or height, to maximize surface area and airflow. The fins should be closely spaced (e.g., 3mm gaps). Include four 5mm diameter mounting holes on the base plate. Visual appearance: anodized black aluminum.

Create a rectangular plate with dimensions 100mm x 50mm x 5mm. Add four M4 clearance holes (4.5mm diameter) in each corner, positioned 10mm from both adjacent edges. The holes should pass through the entire plate.
Design a 50mm x 50mm x 50mm solid cube. Apply a 5mm radius fillet to all 12 edges of the cube. Then, create a 20mm diameter through-hole centered on one of its faces.

Generate an L-shaped bracket from a 5mm thick extrusion. The outer dimensions of the L-shape should be 80mm x 60mm, with both arms being 10mm wide. Add two M5 clearance holes (5.5mm diameter) in each arm, positioned 15mm from the ends of the arms and centered along the arm's width.
Model a solid cylinder with a 40mm diameter and a 60mm height. Apply a 2mm x 45-degree chamfer to both the top and bottom circular edges of the cylinder.
Create a cone with a base diameter of 20mm and a height of 30mm. Drill a 2mm diameter cylindrical through-hole along its central axis, passing from the apex through the center of the base.

Design a 70mm x 70mm x 10mm rectangular plate. Centered on its top face, add a cylindrical boss with a 30mm diameter and a 15mm height. On top of this boss, create a counterbore suitable for an M8 socket head cap screw: an 8.5mm through-hole, a 13mm counterbore diameter, and an 8mm counterbore depth.

Produce a 120mm x 80mm x 3mm rectangular plate. Create a 10x6 grid of 8mm diameter through-holes. The spacing between hole centers should be 10mm in both X and Y directions, with the first hole's center positioned 10mm from the respective plate edges.

Create an assembly of three concentric washers. The first washer is 30mm Outer Diameter (OD), 10mm Inner Diameter (ID), and 2mm thick. The second is 40mm OD, 10mm ID, and 3mm thick. The third is 50mm OD, 10mm ID, and 4mm thick. Stack them concentrically on top of each other.
Model a 100mm long cylindrical shaft with a 20mm diameter. On one end of the shaft, add a 6mm wide, 3mm deep keyway extending 20mm along the shaft's length, centered on the shaft's radius.

Design a 100mm x 100mm x 5mm square plate. Cut out 5 parallel rectangular slots, each 80mm long and 5mm wide, passing entirely through the plate. The slots should be centered on the plate and have a 10mm spacing between their centers.

Design a compression helical spring with the following parameters: 8 active coils, 20mm outer diameter, 2mm wire diameter, and a 40mm free length. The ends of the spring should be squared and ground (flattened perpendicular to the axis) for stable seating.

Create a plastic bottle cap with a 35mm outer diameter and 15mm height. It must feature an M28x1.5 internal thread starting 2mm from the top edge. The outer cylindrical surface should have a straight knurling pattern, simulated by small V-shaped cuts (e.g., 0.5mm deep, 1mm wide at surface, spaced 1mm apart). Add a 2mm high, 1mm thick lip/flange at the bottom outer edge.

Design a spur gear with precise involute tooth profiles. The gear should have 30 teeth, a 2mm module, a 20-degree pressure angle, a 10mm face width, and a 12mm bore. Include a 4mm wide, 2mm deep keyway in the bore. Ensure the tooth geometry is accurately generated.

Model a circular pipe flange with a 150mm outer diameter, an 80mm inner diameter, and a 20mm thickness. It needs 6 uniformly spaced M10 clearance holes (11mm diameter) on a 120mm bolt circle diameter. Additionally, add a raised face gasket surface: 100mm OD, 80mm ID, and 2mm height, concentric with the main bore.

Create a transition piece that connects a square duct (100mm x 100mm) to a circular duct (120mm diameter). The total length of the transition piece is 80mm. The centers of the square and circular openings should be perfectly aligned. Use a loft operation for the main body and ensure a wall thickness of 2mm.

Design a rectangular box with outer dimensions 100mm x 60mm x 40mm. Shell the box to a 2mm wall thickness, making it open on one of the 100mm x 60mm faces. Inside the box, add three vertical reinforcing ribs, each 30mm tall and 2mm thick, spaced evenly along the 100mm length, extending from the base.

Model a curved handle that is 150mm long. Its cross-section is C-shaped (30mm wide, 20mm high, 3mm wall thickness) and it curves in an arc with a 100mm radius. The gripping surface (inner surface of the 'C') should have a subtle texture, such as small pyramidal dimples (0.5mm deep, 2mm square base) patterned across it with 3mm spacing.

Create a 150mm long M12x1.75 threaded rod. Then, design a corresponding M12x1.75 hexagonal nut with standard dimensions (19mm wrench size, 10mm height). Assemble the rod and nut such that the nut is threaded onto the rod by exactly 20mm.

Design a simplified impeller blade. It consists of a base plate (40mm diameter, 5mm thick) from which a single blade extends upwards. The blade is 50mm tall, 10mm thick, starting with a 20mm width at the base and smoothly tapering to a 5mm width at the top, while simultaneously twisting 30 degrees along its height. Use a multi-section loft or sweep for the blade geometry.

Design a rectangular box base with outer dimensions 100mm x 70mm x 30mm and a 2mm wall thickness, open at the top. On one of the 70mm x 30mm faces, integrate a cantilever snap-fit latch mechanism: 20mm long, 5mm wide, 1mm thickness, with a small 1mm hook feature at its free end. Ensure the latch is designed for sufficient flex to engage with a mating part.

Design a full parametric planetary gear set. Include a sun gear, 3 planet gears, and an annulus (ring) gear. Define parameters for module (e.g., 2mm), number of teeth for sun (e.g., 20) and planets (e.g., 10), and calculate the resulting annulus size. Model all gears accurately with involute tooth profiles. Assemble them in a functional arrangement with a carrier for the planet gears, ensuring correct meshing and a precise backlash of 0.05mm between teeth.

Design a custom multi-pin electrical connector consisting of two mating halves. Each half has a unique housing (e.g., oval cross-section, smoothly blended curves, overall dimensions 40x25x20mm) and integrates 8 precisely aligned cylindrical pins (1.5mm dia, 10mm long) or corresponding receptacles. Incorporate a robust bayonet-style locking mechanism with a 30-degree twist lock. Consider precise tolerances for fit, e.g., 0.1mm radial clearance for pins and 0.2mm axial play in the locking mechanism.

Design a single turbine blade using parametric NACA 4-digit airfoil profiles. The blade should sweep and twist along its 100mm length, starting with a NACA 0012 profile at the root and transitioning smoothly to a NACA 2412 at the tip, twisting a total of 45 degrees. The blade's root attaches to a circular disk (50mm dia, 10mm thick) via a 3-lobe fir-tree attachment geometry. Ensure the fir-tree is precisely toleranced for a 0.02mm clearance fit with a corresponding slot.

Model a hydraulic manifold block from a rectangular aluminum block (200mm x 150mm x 50mm). Drill intricate internal fluid passages (e.g., 8mm and 10mm diameters) connecting various external ports. Include 4x G1/4 threaded ports and 2x G1/2 threaded ports. At external port connections, add counterbores for O-rings (e.g., 12mm OD, 2mm depth for G1/4 ports). Ensure internal channels avoid sharp 90-degree turns, using smooth fillets (e.g., 5mm radius) or blended transitions for optimal flow. The internal paths should be defined by a series of points and tangents for sweeping.

Design a single joint of a small robot arm. It consists of two primary links (100mm x 30mm x 10mm each) connected by a central pivot pin (15mm diameter, 40mm long). Integrate mounting features for a NEMA 17 stepper motor (31x31mm bolt pattern) and two 608ZZ bearings (22mm OD, 8mm ID, 7mm width) seats within the links. Ensure smooth rotation and minimal backlash (e.g., 0.01mm gap between rotating parts). The links should also have integrated cable routing channels (e.g., 5x5mm square cross-section) along their length.

Design an axial fan impeller with 7 highly curved blades. The hub is 40mm diameter, 30mm height, with a 10mm through-bore. Each blade is 50mm long, 20mm wide, and has a complex compound curve profile (e.g., defined by multiple interpolated splines) with a varying pitch/angle (e.g., 20 degrees at root, 40 degrees at tip) along its length. Blade thickness tapers from 3mm at the hub to 1mm at the tip. Leading and trailing edges should have a smooth, aerodynamic radius (e.g., 0.5mm). Blades should be uniformly spaced and smoothly blended into the hub.

Create a spherical jigsaw puzzle with a 100mm diameter. It should be composed of 12-15 unique interlocking pieces. The mating surfaces should be complex, organic-shaped, and precisely fit together (e.g., with 0.05mm clearance) to form the complete sphere. Each piece should have unique identifying features (e.g., embossed numbers 1-15, 2mm height, 0.5mm depth) to aid in assembly.

Design a worm shaft (50mm long, 20mm diameter, single start, 10mm lead, 20-degree pressure angle, right-hand thread) and a corresponding worm gear (40 teeth, 2mm axial module, 60mm pitch diameter, 20mm face width, 15mm bore, 4mm keyway). Ensure the profiles are conjugate and mesh correctly with a 0.1mm backlash. Assemble them at the correct center distance, allowing for rotational interaction.

Design a parametric enclosure for electronic components (150mm x 100mm x 40mm overall size, 2mm wall thickness). It should have multiple mounting bosses for a PCB (e.g., 4x M3 standoffs, 5mm height, 6mm OD). On one face, integrate a complex ventilation pattern (e.g., a Voronoi diagram or a custom parametric pattern generated from a scaled SVG outline), cut 1.5mm deep, ensuring a minimum 40% open area while maintaining structural integrity. Include snap-fit clips for a lid on the opposing face.

Design a precision optical mount for a 25mm diameter cylindrical lens. The mount should allow for both coarse (e.g., clamp-based with 2x M4 screws) and fine (e.g., M2 threaded screw driven wedge/lever mechanism with ±5mm travel, 0.01mm resolution per degree of screw rotation) adjustment in at least one axis. The assembly should consist of multiple inter-fitting parts (base, lens holder, adjustment wedge, threaded rod, rotation knob, return spring) with precise tolerances (e.g., 0.02mm slide clearance, 0.05mm backlash in screw mechanism). All parts should be designed for high stability.

Design a solid rectangular block with dimensions 100mm (length) x 50mm (width) x 20mm (height). All 12 edges should have a uniform chamfer of 2mm at 45 degrees. The spatial accuracy required for dimensions and chamfers is ±0.1mm. The visual appearance should be clean and precise.

Create a cylindrical rod 150mm long with a diameter of 25mm. A through-hole of 10mm diameter should be centered along its axis. One end of the rod should have a 1mm fillet radius, and the other end a 1mm chamfer at 45 degrees. Precision for diameters is ±0.05mm.

Construct a flat rectangular plate, 120mm x 80mm, with a thickness of 5mm. It needs four mounting holes, 8mm in diameter, centered 10mm from each corner (e.g., (10,10), (110,10), (10,70), (110,70) in a local coordinate system). All edges of the plate should have a 0.5mm chamfer. Dimensions must be accurate to ±0.05mm.

Model an L-bracket with a base of 60mm x 30mm x 5mm thickness and a vertical arm of 50mm x 30mm x 5mm thickness. The inside and outside corners where the base and arm meet should have a fillet radius of 3mm. All outer sharp edges should have a 0.5mm fillet. Dimensions should be within ±0.1mm.

Generate a T-slot profile extrusion. The base should be 30mm wide and 5mm thick. The vertical stem is 20mm high and 8mm thick. The top 'T' section is 15mm wide and 5mm thick. The bottom of the 'T' slot opening is 11mm wide. All internal corners should have a 1mm fillet, and external corners should have a 0.5mm chamfer. Length of extrusion is 200mm. Spatial accuracy ±0.1mm.

Design a simple washer. Outer diameter 20mm, inner diameter 8mm, thickness 2mm. Both top and bottom edges of the inner and outer diameters should have a 0.2mm chamfer. All dimensions must be accurate to ±0.02mm.

Create a frustum (truncated cone). The bottom base diameter is 50mm, the top base diameter is 30mm, and the height is 40mm. The top and bottom edges should have a 0.5mm fillet radius. Dimensions need to be accurate to ±0.1mm.

Model a basic keycap for a mechanical keyboard. The base is an 18mm x 18mm square with a height of 8mm. The top surface should be slightly concave, with a spherical depression of radius 100mm, starting 1mm from the top edges. All vertical edges should have a 0.5mm fillet. Accuracy ±0.1mm.

Design a simple bottle cap. A cylinder with outer diameter 30mm, height 12mm. The top surface should be flat. The side wall needs to have a knurled pattern. For simplicity, represent the knurling as 30 vertical grooves, 1mm wide, 0.5mm deep, uniformly distributed around the circumference. The bottom inner edge should have a 1mm fillet. Dimensions ±0.1mm.

Construct a rectangular base plate, 150mm x 100mm x 10mm thick. In the center, create a boss feature: a cylinder of 40mm diameter and 15mm height, perfectly centered on the plate. On top of this boss, place a square pyramid 25mm base side, 20mm height, also centered. All sharp edges should have a 0.5mm chamfer. Accuracy ±0.1mm.

Model a standard spur gear with the following specifications: Module 2, 20 teeth, Pressure Angle 20 degrees. The face width should be 15mm. It should have a central bore of 10mm diameter and a 3mm wide keyway. All sharp edges (top and bottom of teeth, bore edges) should have a 0.2mm chamfer. Dimensions and tooth profile accuracy: ±0.02mm. Visual appearance should clearly show the involute tooth profile.

Design a two-part bearing housing for a 608ZZ deep groove ball bearing (OD 22mm, ID 8mm, Width 7mm). The housing consists of two halves that bolt together. Each half should have a semi-circular cutout for the bearing, with a snug fit (tolerance -0.01mm to 0mm on diameter). Include four M3 bolt holes for assembly, arranged in a 30mm square pattern, and two M4 mounting holes on the base for attachment to a surface. All external edges should have 0.5mm fillets. Total assembled dimensions approximately 50mm x 30mm x 20mm. Accuracy ±0.05mm.

Create a T-junction pipe assembly. The main pipe has an outer diameter of 50mm and an inner diameter of 44mm. The branch pipe, perpendicular to the main, has an outer diameter of 30mm and an inner diameter of 24mm. Both ends of the main pipe and the end of the branch pipe should have flanges for connection. Each flange is 10mm thick, extends 15mm beyond the pipe OD, and has four M6 bolt holes on a 70mm (main) and 50mm (branch) bolt circle diameter respectively. The junction itself should be smoothly blended with a 5mm fillet. Dimensions ±0.05mm.

Model a parametric M10x1.5 bolt and a matching hexagonal nut. The bolt should have a hexagonal head (17mm AF - across flats), 8mm thick, and a shank length of 50mm. The threaded portion should be 25mm long, starting 5mm from the head. Represent the thread profile accurately enough to visualize the helix. The nut should be 17mm AF and 8mm thick, with a matching internal thread. All non-bearing edges of both bolt and nut should have 0.5mm chamfers. Thread pitch accuracy is critical for visual representation.

Design a single propeller blade. The blade should be 150mm long. The root (attachment point) should be a rectangular section 20mm x 10mm. The tip should be rounded. The blade profile should transition from a flat rectangular section at the root to an airfoil shape at 50mm, and then gradually twist and taper towards the tip, ending at 5mm thick. The maximum chord length is 30mm at mid-span. Use sweeping or lofting techniques. Visual appearance should be smooth and aerodynamic. Spatial accuracy ±0.1mm.

Construct an electronics enclosure for a small device. It should be a two-part design (top and bottom halves) that snap together. Overall dimensions: 80mm x 60mm x 25mm. The bottom half should have standoffs for a 50mm x 30mm PCB. Include small ventilation slots (e.g., 5mm x 1mm, arrayed) on one side. The snap-fit mechanism should be robust, with at least two latches on each long side. Wall thickness 2mm. Clearance for PCB and internal components 1mm. Accuracy ±0.05mm.

Design a heat sink with a base plate of 100mm x 50mm x 5mm. On top of this, create an array of 20 fins, each 50mm long, 2mm thick, and 30mm high. The fins should be spaced 3mm apart. The fins and base should be a single, monolithic part. All exposed sharp edges of the fins and base plate should have a 0.5mm chamfer. Dimensions ±0.1mm.

Model a simple universal joint (Cardan joint) consisting of three parts: two yokes and a cross. Each yoke should be designed to accept a 10mm diameter shaft. The cross should connect the two yokes, allowing relative rotation. All pivots should be represented by holes for 4mm pins. Ensure sufficient clearance for full angular movement up to 30 degrees between shafts. Dimensions: yokes approximately 40mm long, cross 20mm arm length. Accuracy ±0.05mm.

Create a fluid manifold block. This is a rectangular block 100mm x 50mm x 40mm. It should have four M8 threaded ports on one 100x50 face, spaced 20mm apart. These ports should connect internally to a main drilled passage of 10mm diameter running through the 100mm length of the block. On one 50x40 end face, there should be a larger M12 threaded inlet port connecting to the main passage. All internal passages should be smooth. Dimensions ±0.05mm.

Design a small cam and follower mechanism. The cam should be an eccentric circular disk, 40mm diameter, 10mm thick, with its center of rotation 5mm offset from its geometric center. It has a central bore of 8mm for a shaft. The follower should be a roller type, 15mm diameter, 10mm thick, mounted on an arm. The arm is 50mm long, 10mm wide, 5mm thick, with a 6mm pivot hole at one end and a 6mm shaft hole for the roller at the other. Ensure the follower can track the cam profile smoothly. Accuracy ±0.05mm.

Design a complete Geneva Drive mechanism, comprising a four-slot driven wheel and a driving wheel with a locking arc. The driven wheel has a pitch diameter of 80mm and thickness of 10mm. The driving wheel has a pitch diameter of 40mm and thickness of 10mm. Calculate the precise center distance and slot geometry for smooth, indexed motion with zero backlash at rest. Both wheels should have a central bore of 12mm. The driving wheel requires an offset pin (5mm diameter) to engage the slots and a circular locking segment to prevent rotation when not indexing. All critical dimensions (slot width, pin diameter, locking arc profile) must have a tolerance of ±0.01mm for precise kinematic function. Visual appearance should highlight the intricate interlocking shapes.

Model a miniature planetary gear set. This assembly includes a central sun gear (Module 0.5, 12 teeth), three planetary gears (Module 0.5, 18 teeth each), an outer ring gear (Module 0.5, 48 teeth, internal teeth), and a planetary carrier. All gears have a face width of 5mm. The carrier must accurately position the planet gears around the sun gear and connect to the central axis. The ring gear is stationary. All gears should have central bores for axles (2mm for planets, 4mm for sun/carrier). Gear tooth profiles must be accurate to ensure smooth meshing. All fits should be precise (e.g., planet gear axles in carrier with -0.005mm to 0mm tolerance). Parametric design is highly desired, where changing the module or number of teeth adjusts the entire assembly.

Create a complex turbine blade. The blade is 200mm long. Its root attachment is a fir-tree type dovetail, 50mm wide, 30mm high, with five interlocking features, each feature's dimension accurate to ±0.005mm. The blade airfoil profile needs to be defined by at least 5 distinct cross-sections (e.g., at 0%, 25%, 50%, 75%, 100% span), each having a unique chord length, thickness distribution, and twist angle. Use a complex lofting or sweeping operation to generate the smooth, twisted surface. The leading edge and trailing edge should be very thin (e.g., 0.5mm radius at LE, 0.2mm at TE). The surface finish should be exceptionally smooth for aerodynamic performance.

Design a detailed surgical forceps. This assembly consists of two identical handles/jaws, a pivot pin, and a spring mechanism. Each half should be 150mm long. The handle portion requires an ergonomic, curved grip. The jaw tips must have fine, interlocking serrations (0.2mm pitch, 0.1mm deep) for gripping, precisely aligned when closed. The pivot joint needs a tight fit for a 3mm diameter pin, ensuring smooth, low-friction operation with minimal play (tolerance ±0.005mm for pivot holes). Include a small leaf spring (represented as a separate part, 0.5mm thick, 10mm wide) within the handle assembly to provide opening force. All external surfaces should be smoothly filleted and polished.

Model a single articulated joint module for a small robot arm. This module measures approximately 70mm x 50mm x 40mm and is designed to house a small servo motor (e.g., 20x20x10mm body). It comprises two main structural parts, designed to interlock with precise dowel pins (3mm dia, tolerance ±0.005mm) and M2 bolts. Include precise mounting features for the servo motor, bearing seats for a 10mm shaft (tolerance -0.01mm), and internal channels for cable routing. The exterior should have a functional, robust appearance with chamfers and fillets for stress reduction. This module should allow for easy disassembly and maintenance.

Create a complex impellor for a small centrifugal pump. The impellor has a main disk (50mm diameter, 5mm thick) with a central 10mm bore. It needs 6 curved blades, each 40mm long, 8mm high, and 2mm thick, smoothly transitioning from the central hub to the outer diameter. The blades should have a specific backward curve (e.g., exit angle of 30 degrees from tangent). The inner surface of the blades should be smoothly blended with the hub. All surfaces, especially the blade surfaces, must be very smooth for hydraulic efficiency. Spatial accuracy: blade profiles and angles to within ±0.02mm.

Design a multi-stage coaxial rotary encoder assembly. This involves an inner shaft (5mm dia), an outer sleeve (10mm dia), two encoder disks with intricate optical patterns (e.g., 100 slits on one, 10 on the other, 0.1mm slit width), and a housing that holds these components. The housing includes bearing seats (for 5mm and 10mm bearings, -0.01mm tolerance), optical sensor mounts (for 2mm x 2mm sensors, ±0.02mm position), and cable exits. The optical patterns must be precisely generated and aligned. The entire assembly needs to fit within a 30mm diameter, 25mm high cylindrical volume. Parametric control over slit count is desirable.

Model a miniature pneumatic valve block. This block is 40mm x 30mm x 20mm. It requires three threaded ports (M3) on one face for input/output and three internal intricate air passages (1mm diameter) connecting these ports to a central chamber (5mm diameter, 10mm long). This central chamber then needs to connect to a small solenoid pilot valve mounting face (e.g., 10x5mm face with two M1.5 screw holes and a 0.5mm dia port). All internal passages must be precisely drilled and deburred (represented visually). External features include mounting holes (2x M2) and smooth, clean surfaces. Internal passages accuracy: ±0.05mm for path and diameter.

Design a complex snap-fit electronics enclosure specifically for a credit-card-sized PCB (85mm x 54mm, 1.6mm thick). The enclosure should be a two-part shell with a wall thickness of 1.5mm. It needs internal standoffs for the PCB, precise cutouts for USB-C, HDMI, and micro-SD ports, each with a 0.1mm clearance. Integrate at least four robust, multi-latch snap-fit mechanisms on the perimeter. Additionally, design integrated light pipes for two 3mm LEDs. The external surface should feature subtle, organic curves and texture for improved grip. Accurate dimensioning and clearances (down to ±0.05mm) are crucial for PCB fit and port alignment.

Create a high-precision optical mount for a 25mm diameter lens. This assembly consists of a main cylindrical body (50mm outer diameter, 30mm high), a threaded retaining ring, and a back stop ring. The lens seat inside the body must be perfectly perpendicular to the optical axis and have a 0.01mm tolerance on diameter for the lens fit. The retaining ring, with a fine M30x0.5 internal thread, screws into the main body to hold the lens. The back stop ring should provide a precise focal plane adjustment. The external surface of the retaining ring should have fine knurling for grip. All surfaces must be very smooth, and critical dimensions accurate to ±0.01mm.

Create a rectangular block with dimensions 100mm (length) x 50mm (width) x 20mm (height). Add a circular hole, 15mm in diameter, centered on the top face. Ensure all edges have a 2mm fillet for a smooth appearance. The block should be solid.

Design a simple cylindrical shaft with a diameter of 30mm and a length of 120mm. On one end, create a 5mm deep counterbore with a 20mm diameter, followed by a through-hole of 10mm diameter. On the opposite end, add a keyway slot, 5mm wide and 3mm deep, extending 30mm along the shaft's length. Spatial accuracy: ±0.1mm.

Construct a basic mounting bracket. It should have a 70mm x 40mm rectangular base, 5mm thick. From the center of one 40mm edge, extrude upwards a wall of 50mm height and 5mm thickness, forming an 'L' shape. On this vertical wall, place two 6mm diameter mounting holes, centered 20mm from the top edge and 15mm from each side edge. All internal and external corners should have a 3mm fillet. Visual appearance: smooth, robust.

Model a simple T-slot profile. The horizontal bar should be 40mm wide and 10mm tall. The vertical stem, centered on the horizontal bar, should be 8mm wide at its base, tapering to 6mm wide, and extend 30mm downwards. The 'T' shape should have a total length of 200mm. Maintain sharp, precise corners for the slot geometry.

Generate a hexagonal nut M10. The nominal diameter (across flats) should be 17mm, and the height 8mm. The internal thread should be simulated as a 8.5mm diameter through-hole (for visual representation). Add a 0.5mm chamfer to the top and bottom outer edges of the hexagon for a realistic finish. Accuracy: ISO metric coarse thread standard for dimensions (approximated for hole).

Create a rectangular plate, 150mm x 100mm x 10mm thick. On this plate, create an array of 5x3 (columns x rows) circular holes, each 8mm in diameter. The holes should be spaced 25mm apart horizontally and 20mm vertically, with a 20mm margin from the plate edges. The visual appearance should be clean and precise.

Design a small, simple enclosure base. It should be 80mm x 60mm externally, with a wall thickness of 3mm and a height of 30mm. The bottom should be closed. Add four mounting bosses in the internal corners, 5mm diameter, extending 10mm upwards, each with a 3mm diameter pilot hole. All external edges should have a 1mm fillet. Spatial accuracy: ±0.05mm for mounting features.

Model a short pipe elbow with a 90-degree bend. The pipe has an outer diameter of 50mm and an inner diameter of 40mm. The bend radius to the centerline of the pipe should be 60mm. The straight sections on either end of the bend should be 30mm long. Ensure the transition is smooth. Visual appearance: seamless curve.

Construct a basic gear blank: a cylinder with a 60mm outer diameter, 10mm thickness, and a 10mm through-hole centered for a shaft. Add a 3mm wide, 1.5mm deep keyway in the shaft hole. All edges should be sharp except for the keyway which has a 0.5mm fillet at the base corners. Accuracy: ±0.02mm for shaft hole.

Design a simple stand for a small device. The base is a 60mm diameter circle, 8mm thick. From its center, a 20mm diameter column extends 70mm upwards. At the top of the column, attach a 50mm x 50mm x 5mm thick square plate. All transitions should have a 2mm fillet. Visual appearance: sturdy, elegant.

Model an 'S'-shaped hook. It should be made from a 5mm diameter rod. The overall height of the hook is 100mm. The top and bottom curves should have a radius of 15mm, and the central straight section should be approximately 30mm. Ensure smooth, continuous curvature throughout the hook's path. Visual appearance: polished metal, consistent diameter.

Create a parametric spur gear module. The gear should have 30 teeth, a module of 2mm, a pressure angle of 20 degrees, and a face width of 10mm. Include a 12mm diameter central bore and a 4mm x 2mm keyway. The tooth profile should be an involute, accurately generated. The final part should be a single, solid gear. Spatial accuracy: within 0.01mm for tooth profiles.

Design a custom heatsink. The base is 100mm x 50mm x 5mm thick. From this base, create 15 rectangular fins, each 45mm tall, 1.5mm thick, and 90mm long. The fins should be spaced 2.5mm apart, centered on the base. Add a 2mm fillet at the base of each fin where it joins the main plate. The overall aesthetic should be functional and robust. Visual appearance: brushed aluminum.

Construct a threaded M12 bolt and a corresponding M12 nut as separate parts. The bolt should have a 25mm long threaded section, a 10mm unthreaded shank, and a hexagonal head (across flats 19mm, height 8mm). The nut should be standard M12 (across flats 19mm, height 10mm). Both parts must have accurately modeled external and internal metric coarse threads (pitch 1.75mm) with proper clearances for assembly. Accuracy: thread profiles to ISO standards, ±0.02mm clearance.

Model a simple bottle and screw cap assembly. The bottle body is a cylinder 60mm diameter, 120mm tall, with a 3mm wall thickness. The top 20mm of the bottle neck should have an external thread (e.g., M40x3mm pitch). The cap should match this thread, be 15mm tall, with a 65mm outer diameter and knurled outer surface (simulate with a fine texture or small cuts). Ensure a 0.2mm radial clearance for assembly. Visual appearance: clear bottle, colored cap.

Create an enclosure with a removable lid. The main body is 120mm x 80mm x 40mm (external), with 3mm wall thickness. The lid should be 3mm thick and fit snugly over the body with a 0.1mm gap on all sides. Integrate four simple snap-fit clips, one on each long side and two on the short sides, for the lid to secure to the body. The clips should have a retention lip of 1mm. Visual: clean, functional plastic enclosure.

Design a V-block with a clamping mechanism. The V-block should be 80mm long, 50mm wide at the base, and 40mm tall. The 'V' angle should be 90 degrees. Include a central slot 10mm wide for a clamping bolt. The clamp itself should be a rectangular bar (80mm x 20mm x 10mm) with a 10mm diameter hole. The assembly should show the clamp positioned over the V-block, ready to secure a cylindrical part. All functional edges should be sharp, non-functional edges with 1mm fillets.

Model a cable management clip designed to hold a 5mm diameter cable. The clip should have a flexible 'C' shape with an internal diameter of 5.2mm to allow the cable to snap in. It should have a flat mounting base (30mm x 15mm x 3mm) with two 3mm diameter screw holes. The clip material thickness should be 2mm. Ensure smooth internal surfaces for the cable. Spatial accuracy: ±0.05mm for cable retention features.

Construct a simple piston with two ring grooves. The piston has a 40mm diameter and 50mm height. The pin bore, 15mm diameter, should be centered 20mm from the bottom face. Add two ring grooves, each 2mm wide and 2mm deep, spaced 5mm apart, starting 5mm from the top face. All edges except for the ring groove corners should have a 1mm fillet. Visual appearance: machined, polished.

Design a dovetail joint assembly consisting of two interlocking pieces. Each piece is 100mm long, 40mm wide, and 20mm thick. One piece should have a male dovetail profile (30-degree angle, 10mm deep), and the other a female profile to precisely match. Ensure a slight interference fit (e.g., 0.05mm) for a tight connection when modeled. Visual appearance: wood-like texture.

Generate a Geneva drive mechanism consisting of a four-slot wheel and a driving pin wheel. The driven wheel should have a pitch diameter of 100mm, with four precision slots for the pin. The driving wheel should have a pin at the appropriate radius to engage the slots and a locking segment to hold the driven wheel in place between steps. All clearances for smooth operation (0.1mm) must be precise. Visual appearance: contrasting colors for driver and driven wheel.

Model a double helical (herringbone) gear. The gear has 40 teeth, a normal module of 3mm, a pressure angle of 20 degrees, and a helix angle of 30 degrees. The total face width is 40mm, with a central gap of 5mm between the two helical sections. Include an accurate involute tooth profile and a central bore of 25mm. The transition between the left-hand and right-hand helices must be seamless. Spatial accuracy: 0.005mm for tooth geometry.

Design a complex turbine blade. The blade has an airfoil cross-section that transitions and twists along its 150mm length. The root profile is an NACA 0012, scaling up to an NACA 2412 at the tip. The chord length should vary from 40mm at the root to 60mm at the tip. Additionally, the blade should have a twist of 20 degrees from root to tip. The blade's base should integrate into a 50mm x 20mm rectangular dovetail root. Ensure a smooth, aerodynamic surface. Visual: highly reflective metal.

Create a 6-piece interlocking burr puzzle (e.g., standard cross puzzle). Each of the six pieces must be uniquely shaped but identical in overall dimensions (e.g., 60mm x 20mm x 20mm total volume for each piece before cuts). The pieces must interlock perfectly without gaps, forming a 60mm cube when assembled. The cuts and notches must be precise to allow assembly and disassembly. Accuracy: 0.01mm tolerance for interlocking features.

Model a multi-link articulated robotic arm component. Design a single arm segment (e.g., 150mm long, 40mm square profile) that includes a precise joint interface on each end. One end should have a clevis joint with a 20mm bore and 10mm width, and the other end a tongue joint matching the clevis. Incorporate internal cable routing channels (5mm diameter) and mounting points (4x M4 threaded holes) along its length. The segment should be shelled with a 2mm wall thickness. Accuracy: 0.02mm for joint clearances.

Develop a parametric fan duct for a 60mm diameter fan. The duct should smoothly transition from a square inlet (80mm x 80mm) to a circular outlet (60mm diameter). The total length of the duct is 50mm. Integrate four mounting tabs with 4mm screw holes at the inlet for attaching to a surface, and four similar tabs at the outlet for mounting the fan. The inner surface must be extremely smooth for optimal airflow. The duct should have a 3mm wall thickness. Visual: smooth, matte black plastic.

Construct a miniature crankshaft assembly for a single-cylinder engine. This includes the main shaft, a crank web, and a connecting rod journal. The main shaft is 8mm diameter, 60mm long. The crank offset (distance from main shaft centerline to journal centerline) is 10mm. The connecting rod journal is 5mm diameter, 12mm long. All components should be merged into a single solid part, with fillets (0.5mm) at all transitions for strength. Spatial accuracy: 0.01mm for crank offset and journal concentricity.

Design a complex spring-loaded plunger mechanism. This involves a cylindrical housing (30mm OD, 25mm ID, 50mm long), a plunger rod (24mm OD, 60mm long) with a specific shaped tip (e.g., a 15-degree cone), and an internal helical compression spring. The spring should be represented geometrically (e.g., 20mm OD, 1mm wire diameter, 8 active coils, 30mm free length). The plunger should move freely within the housing with a 0.1mm radial clearance. Include a stop pin slot and a retention feature for the plunger. Visual: translucent housing, metallic plunger and spring.

Model an intricate architectural facade panel. The panel is a 500mm x 500mm square, 10mm thick. It features a repetitive pattern of parametrically varying hexagonal cutouts. The hexagons should start at 20mm edge-to-edge dimension at the center of the panel and gradually scale up to 40mm edge-to-edge at the corners, while maintaining a consistent 5mm spacing between them. The cutouts should be through-holes. Visual: perforated metal panel with a brushed finish.

Create a custom manifold block for pneumatic fittings. The block is 150mm x 80mm x 40mm. It needs two large input ports (G1/4 thread) on one side, and six smaller output ports (M5 thread) on the opposite side. Design internal channels (5mm diameter) to distribute air from the input ports to each of the output ports. Ensure all channels are connected and sealed. The channels should be drilled as straight paths where possible, connecting at precise junctions. All threaded holes should be accurately modeled with appropriate lead-in chamfers. Accuracy: 0.05mm for channel intersections and thread locations.

Create an L-shaped bracket with overall dimensions 100x50x30mm and a uniform thickness of 5mm. Include two 10mm diameter through-holes on each face, centered 15mm from the respective edges. Add a 3mm fillet to the inside corner and a 1mm chamfer to all external sharp edges. The part should appear metallic grey.

Design a simple rectangular enclosure box with external dimensions 80x50x30mm and a uniform wall thickness of 2mm. The box should have an open top. Include four mounting holes, 4mm diameter, in the base, centered 5mm from each corner. The material should visually resemble white plastic.

Model a cylindrical shaft 150mm long and 20mm in diameter. On one end, add a 10mm wide, 5mm deep keyway extending 30mm along the shaft. At 20mm from the opposite end, cut a 2mm wide, 1mm deep groove for a retaining ring. Finish with a 0.5mm chamfer on all sharp edges. The shaft should have a polished steel appearance.

Generate a stack of three identical flat washers. Each washer has an outer diameter of 30mm, an inner diameter of 12mm, and a thickness of 2mm. The washers should be stacked coaxially, with a 0.1mm gap between each, and appear as polished brass.

Extrude a 5-point star profile with an outer radius of 40mm and an inner radius of 15mm. Extrude this profile to a height of 25mm. Add a 10mm diameter through-hole in the exact center of the star. Give the finished part a glossy red finish.

Design a circular pipe flange with an outer diameter of 120mm, a central bore of 50mm, and a thickness of 15mm. Include six equally spaced 12mm diameter bolt holes arranged on a 90mm bolt circle diameter (BCD). The part should have the visual characteristics of cast iron.

Create two distinct parts: First, a cylindrical peg 50mm long and 10mm in diameter, with a 2mm fillet on one end. Second, a rectangular block 40x40x20mm with a 10.1mm diameter through-hole in its center, designed for a loose fit with the peg. Position the peg inserted halfway into the hole. Both parts should be a matte blue color.

Design a flat rectangular plate 150x80x5mm. On one end, cut three parallel slots, each 50mm long and 8mm wide, spaced 15mm apart (center-to-center). The slots should begin 10mm from the nearest edge. Apply a brushed aluminum texture to the plate.

Model a 50mm long segment of an M10x1.5 threaded rod. Use a simplified representation of the thread (e.g., a helical groove rather than a true profile) to indicate the threading. Both ends of the rod should have a 45-degree chamfer. The rod should appear dark grey steel.

Create a handle by extruding a U-shaped profile (outer dimensions 120mm length, 30mm width, with an 8mm wall thickness) to a depth of 20mm. Add two 6mm diameter mounting holes on each end of the U-shape, centered 10mm from the tips. Make the handle appear as matte black plastic.

Generate a spur gear with 20 teeth, a module of 2mm, and a pressure angle of 20 degrees. All dimensions, including tooth profile, should be parametrically derived from the module and number of teeth. Include a 10mm central bore and a 4mm wide keyway. The gear should be 15mm thick and appear as machined steel.

Design a 200mm tall bottle with a circular base (60mm diameter) smoothly transitioning to an oval cross-section at the neck (30x20mm). Shell the body to a 2mm uniform wall thickness. Incorporate a textured, slightly recessed ergonomic grip area around the oval section. Create a threaded neck (M25x2 simplified thread) and a visually matching screw-on cap. Both parts should look like translucent green plastic.

Design a two-part plastic enclosure (top and bottom shell) for a 50x30x10mm PCB. The total external dimensions should be 60x40x20mm. Include screw bosses in the bottom shell for PCB mounting and for joining the two shells. Add a grid of ventilation slots on the sides and a 20x10mm rectangular cutout for a display on the top shell. Integrate snap-fit features for tool-less assembly of the two shells. Parts should be matte black and light grey.

Model a helical compression spring with a wire diameter of 2mm, an outer coil diameter of 20mm, 8 active coils, and a free length of 40mm. The ends should be 'closed and ground,' meaning the first and last coils are flattened perpendicular to the spring axis. The spring should appear as galvanized steel.

Design a custom heat sink. Start with a rectangular base 100x60x5mm. On top, create an array of 20 parallel fins, each 50mm long, 1.5mm thick, and 25mm high, spaced 3mm apart. Include four 5mm diameter mounting holes in the base, centered 10mm from the corners. The fins should have a slight 1-degree draft angle for manufacturability. The heat sink should look like anodized black aluminum.

Create a 'snail' or 'constant velocity' cam profile with a base radius of 30mm, designed to lift a roller follower by 15mm over 180 degrees of cam rotation. Model both the cam (10mm thick with an 8mm central bore) and a simple roller follower (10mm diameter, 10mm thick, with a 5mm central pin hole). Visually depict the cam and follower in an assembled state, where the follower rests on the cam profile. Both parts should be polished steel.

Design an air duct that smoothly transitions from a square opening of 50x50mm to a circular opening of 70mm diameter over a total length of 100mm, with a 90-degree bend in the middle. The duct should maintain a uniform wall thickness of 1.5mm throughout. The internal and external surfaces should be smooth. Appearance: sheet metal.

Design a two-part housing to precisely hold a 6203ZZ ball bearing (outer diameter 40mm, inner diameter 17mm, width 12mm). The housing should allow the bearing to be press-fit with a slight interference fit (e.g., 0.05mm). Include mounting flanges with bolt holes for attachment. The two halves of the housing should clamp together with screw bosses for M4 screws. The parts should be a contrasting color (e.g., dark grey and light grey plastic).

Model a M12x1.75 hex head bolt, 60mm long. Accurately generate the triangular thread profile along the specified length of the shaft using a sweep operation. The bolt head should be hexagonal (20mm across flats, 7.5mm thick). Include a 1mm chamfer on the bolt head and end of the shaft. The bolt should have a realistic steel finish.

Design a two-part plastic shell for a common D-sub 9-pin connector. The shells should snap together securely, have precise cutouts for the connector body and cable entry, and feature textured finger grips on the exterior for ease of handling. The cable entry should accommodate an 8mm diameter cable and include an integrated strain relief feature. The parts should be matte black.

Design an internal involute spline hub and a mating external involute spline shaft. The design should be fully parametric, with variables for number of teeth (e.g., 10), module (e.g., 3mm), pressure angle (e.g., 30 degrees), and spline length (e.g., 40mm). Ensure proper clearance (e.g., 0.05mm) for assembly. The shaft should have a shoulder (50mm diameter) and a 6mm wide keyway. The hub should have a mounting flange (80mm diameter with 4 bolt holes). Both parts should be polished steel.

Create a solid block, 150x100x50mm, serving as a fluid manifold. Design a complex network of internal fluid channels. A main channel (10mm diameter) should run diagonally through the block. Branching off this, create three smaller channels (5mm diameter) that exit to external ports on different faces (e.g., M8x1 threaded ports). All internal channel intersections and transitions must be smoothly filleted (e.g., 2mm radius). Include four threaded mounting holes (M6) on the base and visual indicators (e.g., embossed arrows) for fluid flow direction on the exterior. The material should be translucent acrylic.

Design an intricate, organic-shaped ergonomic handle for a handheld power tool. The handle should conform to typical human hand contours (e.g., 90-110mm grip circumference), include distinct finger grooves, and incorporate a complex textured grip pattern (e.g., small pyramidal bumps or a generative Voronoi pattern) over key contact areas. It must also feature an internal cavity for a trigger mechanism and a battery pack (e.g., 80x40x30mm), and a removable access panel for battery insertion with a snap-fit lock. The handle should appear as overmolded rubber on a hard plastic core.

Design a complex joint mechanism for a quadcopter arm that allows it to fold inwards. This involves at least two main structural components that pivot relative to each other, a central hinge pin (e.g., 8mm diameter), integrated locking features (e.g., a detent or spring-loaded pin activated by a button) to secure the arm in both folded and unfolded positions, and internal channels for cable routing through the pivot point. The geometry should prevent over-extension and ensure precise alignment when unfolded. The assembly should comprise at least 4 distinct parts (structural, pin, lock, button). Appearance: carbon fiber and anodized aluminum.

Design an 8-bladed centrifugal impeller with a 100mm outer diameter. The blades should be aerodynamically curved (e.g., based on a logarithmic spiral or custom spline profiles, ensuring smooth airflow) and seamlessly integrate into a central hub (20mm diameter, 30mm long with a 5mm wide keyway). A curved shroud (top plate) should also be designed to match the blade profiles and have a 50mm central inlet. All parts (blades, hub, shroud) should be parametrically linked and form a single complex assembly. Appearance: polished aluminum.

Design a multi-part gearbox housing that encloses two parametrically generated spur gears (as described in Advanced prompt 1) and their shafts. The housing must include precise bearing seats (e.g., for 6203ZZ bearings, OD 40mm) for each shaft, an input and output shaft port, a lubrication fill/drain port, and mounting flanges. The top cover should be removable, sealed with a specific groove (e.g., 3mm wide, 2mm deep) for an O-ring gasket. All housing dimensions and features must be parametrically linked to the gear module, number of teeth, and bearing sizes. The housing should appear as cast aluminum.

Design a complex microwave waveguide horn antenna. It should smoothly transition from a standard rectangular waveguide cross-section (internal dimensions 22.86 x 10.16 mm, 2mm wall thickness) to an exponentially flaring rectangular horn aperture (e.g., 100x70mm) over a length of 150mm. The flare should be defined by specific mathematical curves (e.g., parabolic or hyperbolic profiles for both E and H plane walls) to optimize radiation patterns and minimize reflections. The external surfaces must be smooth. Appearance: highly polished copper.

Design a multi-piece articulated bracket for a monitor arm. The assembly should consist of at least three pivot points with specific angular range limits (e.g., 180 degrees horizontal, 90 degrees vertical tilt). It must include VESA 75/100 mounting holes on one end, and features for attachment to a desk clamp on the other. Incorporate internal cable management channels throughout the arm segments and design a simplified spring-assisted height adjustment mechanism (e.g., internal channel for gas spring, stops). All joints should use custom designed pins/bushings with precise clearances. The assembly should visually be a mix of matte black and polished chrome.

Design a biomimetic internal scaffold structure inspired by bone trabeculae or cellular networks. This involves generating a complex, interconnected, porous internal geometry within a defined external boundary (e.g., a 50x50x50mm cube). The structure should aim for high strength-to-weight ratio, possibly achieved through a generative lattice or Voronoi pattern, with strut thicknesses ranging from 1mm to 3mm. The external surface of the cube should remain smooth and solid (2mm thick shell), while the interior is filled with this intricate porous structure. The part should be translucent white to show the internal structure.

Design a transparent microfluidic chip (75x25x5mm) with a complex network of internal channels and reaction wells. Include multiple intersecting channels (e.g., 0.5mm wide, 0.2mm deep) that connect various reservoirs (2mm diameter, 1mm deep). Design precise ports for fluid input/output (e.g., 1mm diameter through-holes). Additionally, integrate features representing micro-valves (e.g., small circular depressions or thin membranes for pneumatic actuation) that would block specific channels. The design should also include features allowing for the precise bonding of a cover plate (e.g., alignment pins/holes). The entire chip should be made of clear, polished glass-like material.

Create a rectangular bracket 100mm long, 50mm wide, and 10mm thick. It should have two mounting holes, 8mm in diameter, centered 15mm from each end along the centerline of the 50mm face. Add a 5mm fillet to all sharp edges on one side. The part should be visually smooth, made of a generic gray material.

Design a cylindrical shaft 150mm long and 20mm in diameter. On one end, create a 5mm wide, 3mm deep keyway extending 30mm from the end. On the other end, add a 45-degree chamfer with a 2mm offset. The shaft should appear metallic.

Generate a hollow cube with outer dimensions 60mm x 60mm x 60mm. The wall thickness should be 3mm. All outer edges should have a 3mm fillet. The cube should have an opening on one face, 40mm x 40mm, centered. Color: matte black.

Model a pipe section 80mm long with an outer diameter of 50mm and an inner diameter of 40mm. At one end, add a circular flange with an outer diameter of 80mm and a thickness of 5mm. This flange should have 4 equally spaced 6mm diameter mounting holes on a 65mm bolt circle diameter (BCD).

Create a cylindrical gear blank with a 50mm outer diameter, 10mm thickness, and a 10mm through-hole centered. Add a 2mm wide, 1mm deep keyway to the through-hole, aligned with one of the conceptual gear teeth. This is just the blank, no teeth yet.

Design a block that is 80mm long, 40mm wide, and 30mm tall. Cut a 45-degree angle across the entire width, starting 20mm from one end at the top and extending to the bottom at the other end. This creates a ramp. Add 2mm fillets to the top edges of the ramp.

Create a circular button cap with a 20mm diameter base and a height of 5mm. The top surface should be domed with a radius that makes the peak 2mm higher than the base edge. Include a 1mm lip around the bottom edge for mounting. The cap should have a slightly reflective plastic appearance.
Model a flat washer with an outer diameter of 25mm, an inner diameter of 10mm, and a thickness of 2mm. Ensure smooth, sharp edges.

Design an L-shaped bracket made from 3mm thick sheet metal. The two arms should be 50mm long and 30mm wide. Include two 5mm diameter mounting holes on each arm, centered 15mm from the ends and 15mm from one edge. Add a 2mm fillet to the inner corner of the bend.

Create the head of an M6 hex socket cap screw. The head should be a cylinder 10mm in diameter and 6mm high. On the top face, cut a hexagonal socket with a 4mm flat-to-flat dimension and a depth of 4mm. The top edge of the head should have a 0.5mm chamfer.

Design an M20x2.5 threaded rod, 100mm long, and a corresponding hexagonal nut. The rod should have a standard external metric coarse thread profile (M20x2.5). The nut should be 30mm across flats, 16mm thick, with a standard internal M20x2.5 thread. The nut should have a chamfer on both ends at 30 degrees. Visually, the assembly should look like steel.

Create a rectangular enclosure base (120x80x30mm external, 2mm wall thickness). On one 120mm side, integrate a rectangular vent array (5mm wide slits, 1mm spacing, covering a 30x10mm area). On one 80mm side, design a simple cantilever snap-fit latch feature, 15mm long, 5mm wide, 1mm thick, with a 45-degree locking chamfer on its tip. The part should be made of a textured plastic.

Model a compression spring with an outer diameter of 20mm, wire diameter of 2mm, 8 active coils, and a total free length of 40mm. The ends of the spring should be squared and ground (flattened perpendicular to the axis) over 0.75 turns.

Design a single involute spur gear. Parameters: 20 teeth, module 2, 10mm face width. The gear should include a 15mm through-hole with a 4mm wide, 2mm deep keyway. Generate an accurate involute tooth profile using standard pressure angle (20 degrees) and addendum/dedendum values.

Create a bottle body with a circular base diameter of 60mm and a height of 150mm. The body should taper linearly from 60mm at the base to 40mm at the neck over the first 120mm, then transition to a cylindrical neck of 30mm diameter for the remaining 30mm. The bottle should be hollow with a 2mm wall thickness. All external edges should have a 2mm fillet, and the bottom should be slightly recessed 5mm high, 1mm thick.

Design a single fan blade that sweeps along an arc. The blade should start with a root profile of a 10x5mm rectangle and twist to a tip profile of a 20x2mm rectangle. The sweep path is a 90-degree arc with a 50mm radius. The blade should also have a 15-degree twist from root to tip. The leading edge should be rounded (3mm radius), and the trailing edge sharp (0.5mm fillet).

Model a T-junction for pipes. The main pipe has an outer diameter of 50mm and an inner diameter of 45mm. The branch pipe also has an outer diameter of 50mm and an inner diameter of 45mm, and it joins the main pipe perpendicularly at its midpoint. Ensure smooth transitions at the junction.

Design a simple circular cam with a 50mm outer diameter, 10mm thickness, and a 10mm off-center hole (center of hole is 10mm from the center of the cam). Create a simple follower arm that contacts this cam. The arm should be 100mm long, 10mm wide, 5mm thick, with a semicircular roller (10mm diameter) at its end. The arm should have a pivot hole 8mm in diameter at its opposite end. This is two separate parts designed to interact.

Generate a flat, rectangular plate (100x70x5mm). On one face, create a pattern of through-holes arranged in a hexagonal grid. Each hexagon should have an inscribed circle diameter of 8mm, and the spacing between adjacent hexagon centers should be 10mm. The pattern should cover the central 80x50mm area of the plate.

Design a foot mount for a small device. It should be a square base 40x40mm, 10mm thick. From this base, extrude a cylindrical peg 10mm in diameter and 8mm high. This peg should have a barb feature: a circumferential undercut (V-groove, 2mm deep, 2mm wide) 2mm from the tip, designed to snap into a panel. The base should have four 4mm diameter mounting holes, 5mm from each corner.

Design a planetary gear set consisting of a sun gear, three planet gears, and an internal ring gear. All gears should be involute spur gears with module 2 and 20-degree pressure angle. The sun gear has 20 teeth, 10mm face width, and a 10mm through-hole. The planet gears each have 15 teeth, 10mm face width, and a 6mm through-hole. The ring gear has internal teeth, 50 teeth, and 10mm face width. Design a carrier plate (spider) to hold the planet gears around the sun gear and the ring gear. The carrier should have three equidistant posts for the planet gears and a central shaft bore for the sun gear. The entire assembly should be accurate to within 0.01mm for tooth profiles and gear meshing.

Model a complex aerodynamic airfoil profile for a turbine blade. The 2D profile should be defined by at least 15 coordinate points for both the upper and lower surfaces, clearly defining a distinct leading and trailing edge. Extrude this 2D profile 50mm along its normal to create a blade section. Apply a 1mm fillet to the trailing edge and a 5mm radius blend to the leading edge.

Design a two-part enclosure (top and bottom) for a PCB of 100x60mm. The external dimensions should be 110x70x30mm with a 2mm wall thickness throughout and 1mm fillets on all external edges. The bottom part must include four integrated standoffs with M3 threaded holes for PCB mounting, precisely positioned. Integrate intricate ventilation slots on one side, such as a honeycomb pattern or a wave-like grille. Include four rubber feet recesses on the bottom. The top part must create a matching cover with snap-fit features that mate securely with the bottom part. Include a precise opening for a 20x20mm display, a circular opening for a rotary encoder (10mm diameter), and a row of five 4mm circular button cutouts on the front face.

Design a single finger for a robotic gripper. The finger should consist of two segments (proximal and distal) connected by a pin joint. The proximal segment is 50mm long, 15mm wide, and 10mm thick, with a 6mm diameter pivot hole at one end for connection to the gripper base. The distal segment is 40mm long, 15mm wide, and 10mm thick, with a mating feature to connect to the proximal segment via a 4mm diameter pin. The tip of the distal segment should have a soft, rounded gripping surface (e.g., a large fillet or a partial sphere cutout). Both segments should be hollowed out with 2mm wall thickness for weight reduction and have stress-relieving fillets on all internal corners.

Create a base plate (100x100x10mm) that has a gentle convex curvature (e.g., a radius of 500mm) across its top surface. On this curved surface, loft a complex serpentine channel (e.g., an S-shape or similar) with a semicircular cross-section (5mm diameter). The channel should start precisely at one edge of the plate, traverse the curved surface, and exit at an opposite edge. The centerline path of the channel should follow a cubic Bezier curve defined by at least 4 control points, and the channel must conform precisely to the curved surface of the base plate.

Design an impeller for a centrifugal pump. The main body is a cylindrical disk, 80mm outer diameter, 10mm thick, with a 15mm central bore. It should feature eight curved vanes, each 8mm thick, extending from the central bore to the outer edge. The vanes must have a backward-curved profile, smoothly transitioning from the central bore to the outer rim. The curvature should be defined by a specific mathematical function (e.g., a logarithmic spiral or a complex B-spline). The height of the vanes should gradually decrease from 8mm at the base to 5mm at the tip.

Design a multi-material extruder nozzle for a 3D printer. The main body is cylindrical, 20mm diameter, 25mm long. Internally, design a precise heat break section: a 2mm diameter internal channel, precisely reducing to 0.4mm at the nozzle tip. The transition zone should be smooth and conical. Externally, include a hexagonal wrench flat (10mm across flats, 5mm high) near the tip. Above this, add fine external M6x1 threads (10mm long) for mounting to a heater block. The nozzle tip itself should be a precise conical shape with a 0.4mm exit bore. Implied materials: brass for main body, hardened steel for tip insert.

Model a simplified automotive wheel hub and a matching brake disc. The hub is a cylindrical body (80mm diameter, 50mm deep) with a central 30mm bore. It includes a mounting flange with 5 bolt holes (M12 equivalent, 12.5mm diameter) on a 114.3mm BCD. On the face, add a pilot bore (60mm diameter, 10mm deep). The brake disc is a circular disc (250mm outer diameter, 20mm thick) with a central mounting section that mates precisely with the wheel hub's flange and pilot bore. It should have 5 matching M12 bolt holes. The disc should feature internal ventilation channels (simulated as an annular void with radial ribs) and a finely textured braking surface. The hub and disc should be distinct parts but designed for precise assembly.

Design a section of a gearbox housing. It should encapsulate a pair of meshing involute spur gears (assume module 2, 20 teeth and 40 teeth, 10mm face width). The housing walls should be 5mm thick. Include precisely located bearing bores (20mm diameter) for the gear shafts, ensuring proper center distance for the meshing gears. Integrate mounting flanges with bolt holes (8mm diameter) on a 150mm x 100mm base. Add a complex internal oil channel network (e.g., 5mm diameter swept paths) designed to lubricate the gears and bearings, starting from a central sump and branching out, involving intricate Boolean operations for flow paths.

Design an ergonomic handle for a tool, 150mm long. Its cross-section should smoothly transition from a circular profile (30mm diameter) at the base to an oval profile (40x25mm) in the middle, then smoothly back to a circular profile (25mm diameter) at the top. Along its length, the handle should feature subtle, organically sculpted finger grooves and depressions, creating a comfortable grip. These features should involve complex blending and surface modeling techniques, rather than simple cuts. The overall surface should be smooth, with a rubber-like appearance.

Design a simple square base plate with dimensions 100mm x 100mm and a thickness of 10mm. It should have four counter-bored mounting holes, one at each corner, centered 15mm from each edge. Each hole should have a through-diameter of 5mm and a counter-bore diameter of 9mm with a depth of 4mm. Apply a 2mm fillet to all top edges of the plate and a 1mm chamfer to the bottom edges. Maintain a dimensional accuracy of +/- 0.1mm.

Create a cylindrical stand-off. It should have a main body with a diameter of 20mm and a height of 30mm. On one end, add an M5x0.8 threaded stud, 10mm long, extending from the body. On the opposite end, add an M5x0.8 threaded hole, 12mm deep. All edges should have a 0.5mm chamfer. Ensure threading is represented accurately for visualization (e.g., using `CQ.Workplane.cut_threaded_hole`).

Model a basic L-bracket. The two arms are 80mm long, 30mm wide, and 5mm thick. The bend radius should be 5mm on the inside. Each arm should have two 6mm diameter mounting holes, centered 15mm from each end and 15mm from one long edge. Apply a 1mm fillet to all sharp external edges. The part should be a single, solid body.

Generate a hexagonal nut for an M10 bolt. The nut should have a flat-to-flat distance of 17mm and a thickness of 8mm. The internal thread should be an M10x1.5 (coarse pitch). Chamfer both top and bottom edges of the hex by 1mm at 45 degrees. The model should reflect standard hex nut proportions.

Construct a simple rectangular box (open top) with external dimensions 80mm x 50mm x 40mm (height). The walls and base should all be 3mm thick. Apply a 3mm fillet to all internal vertical edges and a 1mm fillet to all external vertical edges. The overall form should be smooth and uniform.

Create a simple washer. It should have an outer diameter of 20mm, an inner diameter of 8mm, and a thickness of 2mm. All edges, internal and external, should have a 0.2mm chamfer. Ensure precise concentricity between inner and outer diameters.

Design a handle with a circular cross-section. The main body is a cylinder 120mm long and 25mm in diameter. On one end, it tapers down to a 15mm diameter over a 20mm length. On the other end, it has a flat face with a 5mm diameter mounting hole centered on the face. Apply a 1mm fillet to all transitions, ensuring a smooth visual appearance.

Model a stepped shaft. The shaft has three sections: a 25mm diameter section (30mm long), a 20mm diameter section (40mm long), and a 15mm diameter section (20mm long). All steps should have a 1mm fillet radius. One end of the 15mm section should have a 4mm deep, 2mm wide keyway. All diameters must be precise to within 0.05mm.

Generate a solid sphere with a 50mm diameter. Cut a 10mm wide and 5mm deep groove along its equator. Then, drill a 10mm diameter hole completely through the sphere, passing through its center, perpendicular to the plane of the groove. The groove should have a semicircular cross-section.

Create a basic pipe section. It should be a hollow cylinder with an outer diameter of 50mm, an inner diameter of 40mm, and a length of 150mm. Both ends should have a 2mm chamfer on the outer and inner edges. The wall thickness should be uniform throughout.

Design a spur gear with specific parameters: Module 2, 20 teeth, Pressure Angle 20 degrees, Face Width 10mm. It should have a central bore of 10mm diameter and a 3mm wide, 1.5mm deep keyway in the bore. Ensure the tooth profile is accurately generated based on involute curves for proper meshing. The gear should be represented as a single solid part.

Model a custom fan blade. Start with a central hub, 30mm diameter, 15mm thick. Then, design three blades evenly spaced (120 degrees apart). Each blade should be 60mm long, 20mm wide at the hub, tapering to 10mm wide at the tip, and have a slight twist along its length (e.g., 15-degree twist from root to tip). The blade thickness should be 3mm. Connect blades to the hub with smooth fillets (e.g., 2mm radius) for aerodynamic efficiency.

Create a parametric enclosure for a small circuit board. The enclosure has external dimensions of 120mm x 80mm x 40mm (height). It consists of two parts: a base and a lid, designed to snap together or be secured with small screws. The walls should be 2.5mm thick. Include four mounting bosses for a 60mm x 40mm PCB in the base, positioned 5mm from the bottom, with 2mm diameter holes. The lid should have a recessed area for a label (e.g., 100mm x 30mm, 0.5mm deep). Fillet all external edges with 1mm radius. The two parts should be separate solid bodies.

Design a flexible coupling element. It consists of two identical flanged halves and a central connecting element. Each flange is a disk 50mm diameter, 10mm thick, with a 10mm central bore and four M5 clearance holes on a 35mm bolt circle diameter. The connecting element should be a flexible star-shaped insert that interlocks with corresponding recesses in each flange. The recesses should be 5mm deep and shaped to accept the star. The overall assembly length when connected should be 30mm. All three parts must be generated separately.

Model an M8x1.25 screw thread that is 20mm long on an 8mm diameter rod. Use a triangular profile (e.g., ISO metric thread profile) for the helix. The rod should be 50mm long in total, with 15mm of unthreaded section on one end and 15mm on the other. Include realistic root and crest radii for the thread profile to ensure manufacturability and strength.

Generate a helical compression spring. The spring should have an outer diameter of 20mm, wire diameter of 2mm, 10 active coils, and a free length of 40mm. The ends should be squared and ground (flattened) over half a turn for stable seating. Ensure the helix is continuous and smooth.

Create a cam profile for a simple follower mechanism. The cam should have a base circle of 30mm diameter and lift a follower by 10mm over 90 degrees of rotation, dwell for 90 degrees, return to the base circle over 90 degrees, and dwell for the remaining 90 degrees. The cam thickness is 8mm, with a 10mm central bore. Use a simple harmonic motion for lift/return to ensure smooth acceleration profiles. The cam profile must be highly accurate (within 0.01mm) for proper operation.

Design a pipe elbow (90 degrees). The pipe has an outer diameter of 50mm and an inner diameter of 40mm. The bend radius (centerline to centerline) should be 75mm. Ensure smooth internal and external surfaces for optimal fluid flow. All transitions should be precisely formed.

Model a mounting block with cooling fins. The block base is 60mm x 40mm x 10mm thick. On top, add 5 cooling fins, each 50mm long, 25mm high, and 2mm thick, spaced 6mm apart. The fins should have a slight draft angle (e.g., 2 degrees) for manufacturability and rounded tips (e.g., 1mm radius). The base should have two M6x1 threaded holes on one 60mm side, 15mm from the ends, and centered. The fins should be uniformly spaced and parallel.

Create a flanged coupling assembly. It consists of two identical flanges. Each flange is a disk of 70mm diameter and 12mm thickness, with a 20mm central bore. Each flange has 6 through-holes of 8mm diameter on a 55mm bolt circle diameter. One face of each flange has a 5mm deep recess with a 40mm diameter to accept a gasket. The assembly should show the two flanges bolted together (without bolts, just positioned) with a 2mm gap between them for the gasket. The two flanges should be distinct parts.

Design a planetary gear set. This assembly should consist of a sun gear (Module 1.5, 20 teeth), three planet gears (Module 1.5, 15 teeth each), an internal ring gear (Module 1.5, 50 teeth), and a planet carrier. All gears should have a 10mm face width and 20-degree pressure angle. The planet carrier should accurately position the planet gears around the sun and within the ring gear using shafts (e.g., 8mm for sun, 6mm for planets, 12mm for carrier) with 0.1mm clearance. Include appropriate bores for all gears and show the full assembly with gears meshing correctly. All parts must be distinct and precisely positioned.
