The recesses should be designed for a secure, repeatable snap-fit. The lid should also be 2mm thick and sit flush with the enclosure top.

Generate a complete Worm Gear and Worm Wheel assembly. The worm wheel should have 40 teeth, a Module of 2mm, a Face Width of 15mm, and an accurately generated helical tooth profile to mesh with the worm. The worm should be single-start, 2mm Module, with a pitch diameter suitable for the worm wheel, and a cylindrical form. It should have a 10mm through-hole and a 4mm keyway. The worm shaft length should be 80mm, with the threaded section 30mm long. Ensure correct meshing geometry and precise fit between the components for efficient power transmission.

Design a pump housing assembly. It comprises a main body, an impeller, and a cover plate. The main body is a toroidal shape (volute) with an inlet and an outlet port, both 50mm diameter. The impeller is 100mm diameter with 6 backward-curved blades (e.g., Archimedes spiral profile), driven by a central shaft bore (15mm diameter with keyway). The cover plate should seal against the main body and have appropriate mounting bolt holes (6 holes on a 150mm PCD) and a central opening for the shaft. The internal fluid paths must be smooth and well-defined, and the entire assembly should be 200mm diameter, 80mm thick.

Model a ball bearing assembly (e.g., 6205). This requires creating the inner race (bore 25mm, OD 52mm, width 15mm), the outer race (OD 52mm, inner bore for balls, width 15mm), 9 precisely spaced 7.938mm diameter steel balls, and a cage to hold the balls. The races should have accurate deep-groove profiles for the balls. The cage should encapsulate the balls while allowing them to rotate freely with a specified running clearance (e.g., 0.02mm). Focus on precise geometry for clearances and fit.

Create a Universal Joint (Hooke's Joint) assembly. This involves two yokes and a cross-spider. Each yoke has a central shaft bore (15mm diameter, 40mm long) and two parallel arms that hold the cross-spider. The arms have bores (10mm diameter) for the cross-spider pins. The cross-spider has four pins (10mm diameter, 25mm long) arranged at 90 degrees to each other. All components must fit precisely with minimal play (e.g., 0.05mm clearance), allowing for free rotation around the joint axes. Include small fillets on stress concentration points for durability.

Design a multi-stage centrifugal impeller (2 stages). Each impeller stage has 8 backward-curved blades (e.g., log-spiral or custom polynomial curve) with a hub and shroud. The first stage impeller has an inlet diameter of 40mm and an outlet diameter of 100mm. The second stage has an inlet of 50mm and an outlet of 120mm. Both impellers share a common central shaft bore (20mm diameter with a keyway). The blades should transition smoothly from the hub to the shroud and be accurately contoured for fluid dynamics. The two impellers should be distinct parts but designed to be assembled coaxially, with precise axial spacing.

Model a complex manifold block. The block is 200mm x 150mm x 100mm. It must contain several intersecting internal channels. For example, three 20mm diameter input channels entering one face, converging into a 30mm diameter central mixing chamber, which then splits into two 25mm diameter output channels exiting another face. All channels must have smooth internal transitions and appropriate connection ports (e.g., G1/2 threaded bosses) on the exterior. Visualize the internal geometry using advanced boolean operations or by sketching and extruding/sweeping paths precisely.

Design a robotic gripper finger. This is a single, articulated finger with a complex external profile for gripping objects. It includes a base mount (50mm x 30mm x 20mm with two 6mm mounting holes), a main knuckle joint, and a distal phalanx. The knuckle should be a pivot joint allowing 45 degrees of rotation, with a 10mm diameter pin and defined stop mechanisms. The finger segments should have ergonomic curvature and internal cavities for potential wiring or sensors (represented as 5mm diameter internal channels). The distal end should feature a textured gripping surface (e.g., a pattern of small pyramids or ridges, 1mm high, 2mm base) for enhanced friction.

Create a fully parametric, variable-pitch screw conveyor section. The central shaft is 50mm diameter, 500mm long. The helical flighting should have an outer diameter of 200mm. The pitch should smoothly vary from 150mm at one end to 250mm at the other end. The flighting thickness is 5mm, maintaining a consistent normal thickness. This requires a complex sweep operation with a variable twist and scaling, ensuring smooth material flow along the helix. The geometry should be precise enough for manufacturing with minimal internal stress.

Model a complete engine piston assembly, including the piston body, two compression rings, and one oil control ring, and the piston pin. The piston body is 80mm diameter, 70mm tall, with precise grooves for the rings (e.g., 2x 2mm wide, 4mm deep compression ring grooves; 1x 4mm wide, 3mm deep oil control ring groove). It includes a bore for the 20mm diameter piston pin (wrist pin). The rings are 1.5mm thick. The piston crown should be slightly domed, and internal ribbing for strength (e.g., two vertical ribs connecting pin bosses to crown) should be present. All components must fit together with realistic clearances (e.g., 0.1mm radial clearance for rings, 0.05mm for pin) for functional operation.

Design a bicycle pedal body. It should be 100mm long, 70mm wide, and 20mm thick at its center. It needs a central threaded bore for a standard pedal spindle (e.g., 9/16 inch x 20 TPI, left-hand thread on one side, right-hand on the other, but just model one side for simplicity). The pedal body should have a slightly concave top surface for foot grip. Include several removable pins for traction (represented by 4mm diameter, 3mm deep holes with 1mm wide boss around them, arranged in a functional pattern). The overall shape should be ergonomic, with rounded edges and internal weight-saving cutouts (e.g., a shell operation with internal bracing of 2mm thickness), ensuring structural integrity.

Create a simple L-shaped mounting bracket with overall dimensions of 60mm (length) x 40mm (height) x 3mm (thickness). It should have two 6mm diameter through-holes on each leg, positioned 10mm from the edges. Add a 5mm fillet to the inside corner for strength. Focus on clean edges and precise hole placement, with a tolerance of +/- 0.1mm.

Design a rectangular plate, 100mm long by 50mm wide and 5mm thick. Create a 3x2 array of countersunk holes for M4 screws (specifically, 4.5mm through-hole diameter, 8mm countersink top diameter, 90-degree countersink angle) with 20mm spacing horizontally and 15mm vertically. The array should be centered on the plate. All dimensions should be accurate to 0.1mm, and the visual appearance should be that of a precisely machined metal plate.

Model a cylindrical boss with a base diameter of 40mm and a height of 25mm. From the top, create a coaxial stepped bore: 15mm diameter extending 20mm deep, then transitioning to a 10mm diameter through-hole for the remaining 5mm. Ensure smooth, sharp transitions between steps and accurate depths. The bottom face of the bore should be flat.

Design a basic rectangular enclosure body (80x50x30mm external dimensions, 2mm wall thickness) with an open top. Create a separate, simple lid that fits snugly onto the top of the enclosure with a 0.1mm clearance. The enclosure body should have four 3mm diameter through-holes for mounting near the corners of the base (5mm from all edges). The appearance should be a simple plastic-like finish.

Generate a standard M10 hexagonal nut. The hex flat-to-flat dimension should be 17mm, and the thickness should be 8mm. Include an M10x1.5 (metric coarse) internal thread profile. The external faces should have a 0.5mm chamfer at 45 degrees. Visual appearance should represent a standard metallic nut with clean, sharp features.

Model a stepped shaft, 120mm long. From one end: 25mm section (20mm diameter), then 40mm section (15mm diameter), then 30mm section (10mm diameter), finally 25mm section (8mm diameter). Add a 2mm wide, 1mm deep keyway along the 15mm diameter section, starting 5mm from its larger shoulder and extending 30mm. All steps should be perfectly coaxial and transitions precise to within 0.05mm.

Create a circular disk with an outer diameter of 80mm and a thickness of 8mm. It should have a central through-hole of 12mm diameter. Additionally, create a circular pattern of six 6mm diameter holes, equally spaced on a 60mm pitch circle diameter (PCD). All holes must be perfectly perpendicular to the disk faces. The surface should be smooth.

Design a 500mm long T-slot extrusion profile. The cross-section should represent a standard 20x20mm T-slot profile (e.g., base width 20mm, overall height 20mm, slot width 6mm, slot depth 6mm, T-head width 10mm). Ensure sharp, clean edges and a consistent cross-section along the entire length, characteristic of an aluminum extrusion.

Model a solid block, 70mm x 40mm x 20mm. Apply a 5mm x 45-degree chamfer to all four edges of the top face. Additionally, create a 10mm diameter through-hole centered on the top face. The block should appear solid and precisely machined, with all features accurate to 0.1mm.

Design a simple cylindrical tube connector. It should have a main body, 50mm long and 25mm outer diameter, with a 20mm inner diameter. On each end, add a smooth, 15mm long transition flare that uniformly increases the outer diameter to 30mm and the inner diameter to 25mm, allowing for easy tube insertion. The internal and external surfaces should be perfectly smooth for fluid flow.

Design an assembly of two interlocking spur gears. Both gears should have a module of 1, a pressure angle of 20 degrees, and a face width of 10mm. The first gear (pinion) should have 20 teeth, and the second gear should have 40 teeth. Ensure precise involute tooth profiles for smooth meshing, and model them positioned on parallel axes 30mm apart (center distance). Each gear should have a central 8mm bore. Visual appearance should be that of precision-cut metal gears.

Create a two-part snap-fit enclosure. The base should be a rectangular box (100x60x25mm external) with 2mm wall thickness. The lid should fully cover the base. Integrate four cantilever snap-fit features on the lid's long sides (two per side, 5mm wide, 1.5mm thick, 8mm long flex arm) that engage with corresponding recesses in the base. Ensure a 0.2mm overall clearance for assembly and a positive snap action. Include four internal mounting bosses (for M3 standoffs, 5mm diameter, 8mm height) on the base. The material appearance should be an opaque plastic.

Design an axial flow fan impeller, 80mm outer diameter, with a 20mm central hub (10mm height). It should feature 5 blades. Each blade should be 2mm thick, smoothly transitioning from the hub to the outer diameter. The blade geometry must incorporate a continuous 10-degree twist from root to tip and a custom airfoil-like curvature along its chord for efficient airflow. Blades should be evenly distributed radially, and all surfaces should be smooth and aerodynamic.

Model a fluid manifold block, a 50x50x50mm cube. It should contain three orthogonal internal fluid channels (5mm diameter) passing entirely through the block, intersecting at the center. On two opposing faces, add two tapered ports (e.g., M8 threads for fittings, 10mm length) that smoothly connect to the internal channels. Ensure the internal geometry is free of sharp corners where flow turns, and all internal surfaces are smooth for optimal flow. The block should appear solid and precisely machined.

Generate a helical compression spring. The spring should have a wire diameter of 2mm, a mean coil diameter of 20mm, and 8 active coils. The ends should be closed and ground flat, with a free length of approximately 30mm. Ensure the helical path is continuous, consistent, and accurate to within 0.05mm. The visual appearance should be that of a metallic spring.

Design the driver and driven wheels for a 4-slot Geneva mechanism. The driven wheel should have a 100mm diameter, with four precisely spaced slots (6mm wide, 25mm deep) for indexing. The driver wheel should have a pin (8mm diameter, 10mm length) offset from its center to engage the slots. Model them as an assembly, accurately positioned for the pin to enter a slot, showing the required clearances (0.5mm between pin and slot walls). Both parts should have central bores (10mm diameter) for mounting.

Create an ergonomic handle, 120mm long. Its cross-section should smoothly transition from a 25mm circular profile at one end to an elongated elliptical profile (30x20mm) in the grip area, then back to a 20x20mm square profile at the other end. Incorporate subtle finger grooves or a textured surface (e.g., using a fine, repeating pattern of small hemispherical bumps 1mm diameter, 0.5mm height) on the grip section for enhanced tactile feel. Smooth, organic surfacing is crucial for the visual appearance.

Model a V-belt pulley with an 80mm outer diameter, 30mm width, and a central bore of 15mm. The pulley should feature a standard 'A-section' V-groove (e.g., 13mm wide at top, 6mm deep, 34-degree angle) accurately centered. Include a 5mm square keyway (2.5mm deep) in the 15mm bore. All edges should have a 0.5mm fillet to prevent wear and ensure smooth operation. The visual appearance should be a machined metallic part.

Design a rack (150mm long, 12mm high, 10mm thick) and a pinion gear (20 teeth, module 1.5, 20-degree pressure angle) that mesh correctly. The rack's teeth should be precisely cut into one face. The pinion should have an 8mm central bore with a 3mm square keyway. Model them as an assembly showing the teeth in engagement, with minimal backlash (e.g., 0.05mm). Ensure the tooth profiles are accurate involute curves.

Create a ball-and-socket swivel joint as a two-part assembly. The socket part should be a 40x40x30mm block with a spherical recess (20mm radius). The ball part should have a matching spherical protrusion (19.9mm radius, for 0.1mm clearance). The socket should also include a groove for a retaining ring (e.g., 1mm wide, 1mm deep, 22mm diameter) to secure the ball. The ball part should have a 10mm diameter, 25mm long shaft extending from it. All spherical surfaces must be perfectly smooth.

Design a parametric planetary gearbox assembly including a sun gear (20 teeth), three planet gears (15 teeth each), and an internal ring gear (50 teeth). All gears must be module 1.25, 20-degree pressure angle, and 12mm face width, with precise involute tooth profiles. Create a planet carrier that holds the planet gears via 8mm diameter pins (0.1mm clearance) and ensures their correct meshing with both sun and ring gears. The sun gear and carrier should have 10mm diameter central bores. Ensure all components are perfectly aligned, with 0.05mm backlash between meshing teeth and appropriate radial clearances (0.1mm) for functional rotation. The output should be the assembly of these four distinct parts, appearing as precision-engineered steel.

Model a complex fluid manifold block (150x100x50mm). It must feature an intricate network of internal channels (8mm diameter throughout) that split into three distinct paths, then merge back into one, with smooth, radius-blended transitions at all junctions (e.g., 5mm radius). Within one of the splitting channels, integrate a series of three internal baffles or fins (1.5mm thick, 10mm long) that are smoothly blended into the channel walls, designed to redirect flow. Include four threaded ports (e.g., M10, 1.5mm pitch, 15mm length) on various external faces, precisely aligned with the internal channels, and one large flanged inlet (50mm diameter, 5mm thick flange) at one end. All internal surfaces must be perfectly smooth for minimal flow restriction.

Design a single articulated joint segment for a small robot arm. This involves two distinct arm links, each U-shaped in cross-section (outer dimensions 30x20mm, 2mm wall thickness, 100mm long). These links should connect via a central pivot joint, accommodating a standard 688ZZ bearing (8mm ID, 16mm OD, 5mm W) with 0.05mm interference fit for the outer race and 0.1mm clearance for the inner race. One arm link should integrate a mounting bracket for a micro servo motor (e.g., 23x12x22.5mm dimensions, with 2mm screw holes for M2 screws) precisely positioned relative to the pivot axis. All components must fit with 0.1mm clearance, and the assembly should show the two links pivoted around the bearing, ready for motion. The material appearance should be anodized aluminum.

Generate a single turbine blade (50mm height). The blade's cross-section should be defined by a NACA 4-digit airfoil (e.g., NACA 0012) scaled to a 15mm chord at the root and 10mm chord at the tip. The blade must exhibit a continuous 20-degree twist from root to tip and a 10-degree forward sweep. It should smoothly connect to a 30x10x5mm rectangular root attachment feature at its base and a small 2mm thick, 15mm long shroud tip feature at its top. Focus on the smooth, complex, double-curved surface generation and precise blending of features, accurate to 0.01mm for aerodynamic integrity.

Design a two-part custom housing for a 20-pin D-sub connector (approx. 53x12x16mm, male or female). The housing (overall 60x20x25mm) should fully encapsulate the connector, providing robust strain relief for a 6mm diameter cable entry at one end. It must incorporate a secure, tool-less snap-fit assembly mechanism along its long edges, ensuring a positive lock. Internal features include precise standoffs and mounting points for the connector PCB (0.1mm clearance from all internal walls), and a molded cable clamp. The external visual appearance should include subtle ergonomic contours and a matte, textured finish, like injection-molded plastic.

Create a single, highly complex 3D interlocking puzzle piece (e.g., part of a 6-piece burr puzzle). The overall bounding box for the piece should be 30x30x30mm. It must feature multiple concave, convex, and undercut geometries, including at least three distinct interlocking features (e.g., L-shaped, T-shaped, and dovetail cuts) that would engage with other hypothetical pieces. All features should have 0.1mm clearance where they meet the bounding box of hypothetical mating parts. The visual representation should highlight the intricate, non-trivial geometry required for interlocking, appearing as a smooth, solid block of wood or plastic.

Design a compact solenoid valve body (external 40x20x20mm) suitable for controlling fluid flow. This requires modeling complex internal passages: a main inlet (M6 thread) splitting into two 4mm diameter channels around a central plunger bore (8mm diameter), then merging into an outlet (M6 thread). Include a precisely machined conical or flat seating surface for a hypothetical plunger at one end of the plunger bore, ensuring a perfect seal (0.02mm accuracy for seating). A mounting feature for a cylindrical solenoid coil (15mm diameter, 25mm height, 2mm wall thickness) must be integrated onto one side. All internal transitions should be smooth for minimal flow resistance.

Model the top half of an ergonomic computer mouse shell, approximately 120mm long, 70mm wide, and 40mm high at its peak. This involves generating highly organic, double-curved surfaces to form the main body, with seamlessly integrated cutouts for two main buttons, a scroll wheel, and two side buttons. The internal side should feature at least five precise mounting bosses (for M2 screws, 4mm diameter, 3mm height) and an interlocking lip (0.8mm thick, 0.1mm clearance) along its perimeter to mate with a hypothetical bottom shell. The visual appearance should convey a smooth, tactile, and highly ergonomic shape, resembling a consumer electronic product.

Design a centrifugal impeller with a 10mm central bore and an overall height of 15mm. It should have an inlet diameter of 30mm and an outlet diameter of 80mm. Integrate six backward-curved blades (1.5mm thickness). Each blade's geometry must be a complex 3D surface, transitioning from an axial orientation at the hub inlet to a radial orientation at the outer periphery, incorporating a specific curvature for fluid acceleration. The blades should be smoothly blended into both the backplate and a hypothetical shroud (or define the blade extent in 3D space). Precision (0.02mm) and smooth surfacing are critical for aerodynamic performance.

Create a rectangular air vent assembly (150mm wide x 100mm high, 20mm deep frame). It should contain an array of five horizontal louvers (15mm height each, 1.5mm thick). Each louver should have an airfoil cross-section (e.g., a simple symmetric NACA 0008 profile). Design pivot points for each louver that allow them to rotate synchronously from 0 degrees (closed) to 90 degrees (fully open). The louver angle must be a single controllable parameter. The frame should provide clear mounting points for the entire assembly, and all louvers must rotate freely within the frame with a 0.5mm clearance. The visual appearance should be a functional plastic or metallic vent.

Create a sturdy L-bracket. It should have a base plate of 100x50x5mm and a vertical arm of 50x50x5mm. The vertical arm should be centered along the 100mm length of the base plate. Add a 10mm radius fillet to the internal corner where the two plates meet. Drill two M5 clearance holes (5.5mm diameter) centered 20mm from each end on the 100mm base plate and one M5 clearance hole centered on the vertical arm, 25mm from its top edge. All external sharp edges should have a 1mm chamfer.

Design a simple cylindrical battery holder. It should be an open-top cylinder with an internal diameter of 18.5mm (for an 18650 battery) and an internal depth of 65mm. The wall thickness should be 2mm, and the base thickness 3mm. Add two mounting holes, 3mm in diameter, on the base, offset 15mm from the center along the X-axis. Include a 0.5mm fillet on all internal and external sharp edges.

Model a basic pipe adapter. Start with a 50mm long cylinder with an outer diameter of 30mm and an inner diameter of 20mm. At one end, flare out to an outer diameter of 40mm over a length of 10mm, while maintaining the 20mm inner diameter. At the other end, add a flange with an outer diameter of 50mm and a thickness of 5mm. The flange should have four 6mm diameter mounting holes equally spaced on a 40mm pitch circle diameter (PCD). Apply a 1mm chamfer to the outer edges of the flange.

Construct a simple T-junction for a square duct system. The main duct segment should be 100x50x50mm. A secondary duct of 50x50x50mm should join perpendicular to the center of one of the 100x50mm faces of the main segment, forming a 'T' shape. Ensure the internal walls are flush. The wall thickness for both ducts should be 2mm. Chamfer all external edges with 1mm.

Create a decorative 'donut' shape. Start with a torus defined by a major radius of 30mm and a minor radius of 10mm. Then, cut a cylindrical hole of 5mm diameter through the center of the torus, perpendicular to its main plane. Apply a 1mm fillet to the inner and outer edges of this central hole.

Design a basic desk organizer tray. It should be a rectangular box, 200mm long, 100mm wide, and 30mm high. The wall thickness should be 2mm, making it hollow. Divide the interior into three equal compartments along the 200mm length using 2mm thick dividers. Round all external corners with a 5mm radius fillet and all internal corners with a 1mm fillet.

Model a simple hexagonal bolt head and a section of its shaft. The hexagonal head should have an across-flats dimension of 13mm and a height of 8mm. The shaft should be a cylinder 8mm in diameter and 20mm long, extending from the bottom center of the hex head. Add a 0.5mm chamfer to the top edges of the hexagonal head and a 1mm chamfer where the shaft meets the head.

Create a flat, rectangular base plate, 150mm long, 80mm wide, and 5mm thick. On one 80mm edge, extrude a solid triangular prism upward, 20mm high, running the full 80mm width. The triangular cross-section should have a base of 20mm and a height of 20mm (right-angled triangle). Chamfer all sharp edges of the triangular prism with 1mm.

Model a circular stepped shaft. It starts with a 30mm diameter section, 40mm long. It then steps down to a 20mm diameter section, 30mm long. Finally, it steps down to a 10mm diameter section, 20mm long. Add a 1mm fillet at each diameter transition.
Design a simple washer with an outer diameter of 20mm, an inner diameter of 10mm, and a thickness of 2mm. Add a 0.5mm chamfer to both the inner and outer top and bottom edges.

Design a parametric spur gear. It should have 20 teeth, a module of 2mm, and a pressure angle of 20 degrees. The face width should be 10mm. Include a central bore of 10mm diameter and a 3x3mm keyway slot. Ensure the involute tooth profile is accurately generated. All sharp edges should have a 0.2mm chamfer for manufacturing purposes.

Create a fluid manifold block. Start with a main rectangular block 100x50x40mm. From one 100x40mm face, extrude three cylindrical bosses, 20mm diameter, 15mm high, spaced evenly along the 100mm length. Each boss should have a 10mm diameter through-hole. Connect these three through-holes internally with a single 8mm diameter channel running horizontally through the block's center. Add a G1/4 (13.157mm diameter) threaded port on a 50x40mm face, centered, intersecting the main channel. Apply a 1mm fillet to the base of each boss and 0.5mm chamfers to all port openings.

Model a complex ergonomic handle. The main body should be a sweep of an elliptical profile (major axis 30mm, minor axis 20mm) along a 150mm long 3D spline curve that gently bends and twists by 45 degrees. Along one side, create three finger grooves, each defined by a circular cut of 8mm radius, spaced 20mm apart. Integrate a mounting base at one end: a 40x40x10mm rectangular block with four M4 (4.5mm diameter) counterbored holes for flat-head screws (counterbore 8mm diameter, 4mm deep) on a 30mm square pattern. The handle surface should be smooth, with all sharp edges filleted by 1mm.

Design a custom enclosure for a small electronic device. It consists of two parts: a base and a lid. The base is 80x60x25mm with a wall thickness of 2mm. It should have four internal mounting bosses, 5mm diameter, 10mm high, with M3 (3.3mm diameter) threaded holes, located 10mm from each corner. The lid should match the base dimensions, also with a 2mm wall thickness. It should incorporate a recessed area (50x30mm, 1mm deep) for a label and two snap-fit hooks on one of the 60mm sides, designed to engage with corresponding slots in the base. The base should have four rubber feet receptacles, 10mm diameter, 2mm deep, at each corner. All external edges should have a 2mm fillet.

Create a pulley wheel with a V-groove. The overall diameter is 80mm, and the total thickness is 30mm. The central hub is 30mm diameter, 30mm thick, with a 12mm central bore and a 4x4mm keyway slot. The V-groove should be centered on the pulley's outer edge, with a 10mm depth and a 30-degree included angle. The groove bottom should have a 1mm fillet. Add three lightening holes, 15mm diameter, equally spaced on a 55mm PCD, cut through the pulley body, excluding the hub. All external sharp edges should have a 1mm chamfer.

Model a complex thread for a custom screw. The thread should be a modified square thread, with a pitch of 5mm, a depth of 3mm, and a flat width of 2.5mm at both crest and root. The core diameter of the screw shaft is 15mm. The thread should extend 50mm along the shaft. The start of the thread should be smoothly blended into the shaft using a 2mm radius fillet.

Design a heat sink with radial fins. The base is a 60mm diameter cylinder, 5mm thick. From this base, extrude 12 trapezoidal fins radially outwards. Each fin should be 2mm thick at the base, 1mm thick at the top, 20mm high, and extend from a 20mm central hub diameter to the 60mm outer diameter. The fins should be evenly spaced. The outer edges of the fins should be rounded with a 0.5mm radius. Include four M3 (3.3mm diameter) through-holes on a 40mm PCD on the base.

Create a pipe bend with internal flow straighteners. The main pipe has an outer diameter of 50mm and a wall thickness of 3mm, bending at a 90-degree angle with a bend radius of 75mm (centerline). Inside the bend, place three equally spaced, 2mm thick, flat flow straighteners, oriented parallel to the plane of the bend, extending from the inner to the outer wall of the pipe. These straighteners should be smoothly blended into the pipe walls with 1mm fillets.

Model a customized optical mount. It should be a rectangular block, 70x50x30mm. On one 70x30mm face, create a V-groove mounting channel, 10mm deep, with a 90-degree included angle, centered along the 70mm length. On the opposite 70x30mm face, drill two M6 (6.8mm diameter) tapped holes, 15mm deep, centered 20mm from each end. On the top 70x50mm face, create a circular recess, 25mm diameter, 5mm deep, with a central M4 (4.5mm diameter) tapped hole. Add a 1mm chamfer to all external edges and a 0.5mm fillet to the bottom of the V-groove.

Design a toggle clamp arm. It starts as a rectangular profile, 20mm wide, 10mm high, 120mm long. At one end, it widens into a circular pivot boss, 30mm diameter, 15mm thick, with a 6mm central through-hole. At the other end, it tapers to a 10mm wide section with a rounded tip, incorporating an M6 (6.8mm diameter) tapped hole, 10mm deep, for a clamp foot. The transition from the rectangular profile to the pivot boss should be smooth with 5mm fillets. All other sharp edges should have a 1mm fillet.

Design a parametric turbine blade. The blade has an airfoil profile defined by 5 cross-sections along a 150mm length. The root profile is 50mm chord, 10mm thick, with a specific NACA 0012 profile. The tip profile is 30mm chord, 6mm thick, with a similar but scaled profile, rotated by 30 degrees relative to the root to induce twist. The blade tapers linearly in chord and thickness. The root attachment features a dovetail joint (30mm wide, 15mm deep, 60-degree angle) suitable for a turbine disk. Ensure smooth lofting between profiles and intricate blending of the dovetail into the blade. All surfaces must be free of sharp edges, with fillets of 0.5mm minimum.

Model a complex, multi-chambered gearbox housing. It consists of two interlocking halves. The overall dimensions are 200x150x100mm. Each half should have internal walls defining two distinct gear chambers and a lubrication reservoir, with a minimum wall thickness of 5mm. Include mounting points for four bearings (e.g., 20mm diameter recesses, 10mm deep, with 10mm through-holes) for input and output shafts, ensuring precise alignment between the two halves. Integrate cooling fins on the exterior (e.g., 10 fins, 3mm thick, 15mm high, running along the 200mm length). Include draft angles of 2 degrees on all internal and external vertical faces for manufacturability (e.g., injection molding). Add a threaded fill port (M10, 10mm deep) and a drain plug (M8, 8mm deep) on the exterior, with corresponding internal passages. All sealing faces between halves should have a 0.5mm groove for an O-ring (2mm width, 1mm depth).

Create an advanced adjustable quick-release clamp assembly. It comprises: a main jaw body (150mm long, with one fixed jaw and a sliding channel), a sliding jaw (fits precisely within the channel of the main jaw, allowing smooth movement), an Acme threaded rod (M12x3mm pitch Acme thread, 100mm long, with a square drive end), an Acme nut (integrates into the sliding jaw, precisely mating with the threaded rod), an ergonomic T-shaped handle (attaches to the threaded rod for manual adjustment), and a swivel pad (attached to the end of the sliding jaw via a ball joint for adaptable gripping). Consider clearances for movement (0.1mm nominal), and proper thread profiles. Ensure the assembly can be parametrically adjusted for jaw opening and securely fastened. All gripping surfaces should have a light knurling pattern (0.5mm diamond pitch).

Design a hydraulic manifold block for multiple valve functions. The main block is 250x100x60mm. It needs to accommodate four standard D03 (ISO 4401-03) valve patterns on its top face, evenly spaced. Each valve pattern requires intricate drilling for pressure, tank, and two work ports (e.g., specific drill diameters and depths, counterbores, and counterdrills according to D03 standard). Internally, create a common pressure rail and a common tank rail, each 10mm diameter, running the full length of the block. All valve ports must connect to these rails or to dedicated work port passages that exit the sides of the block (e.g., four M14 BSPP ports per side). Ensure all internal passages are smoothly blended (1mm fillets) and accessible for manufacturing if necessary.

Model a complex camera gimbal component. This part acts as an interface between a drone frame and a camera mounting plate. It's a highly organic, lightweight structure, approximately 80x80x50mm. It should feature multiple mounting points with specific hole patterns for drone attachment (e.g., four M3 countersunk holes on a 60mm square), and a precise 3-axis bearing mount system (e.g., three sets of 20mm diameter, 5mm deep recesses for miniature bearings, with 5mm central through-holes, oriented orthogonal to each other). Incorporate intricate lattice-like cutouts or honeycomb patterns on non-structural surfaces for weight reduction while maintaining rigidity. Design internal channels for cable routing, accessible from the exterior. All external edges should have a smooth blend, with variable fillets ranging from 0.5mm to 3mm.

Create a high-fidelity rendering of a modern car wheel rim. The rim should be 18 inches in diameter (457.2mm), 8 inches wide (203.2mm). It needs to feature a complex 5-spoke design where spokes smoothly transition from the central hub to the outer rim. The central hub accommodates a 5x114.3mm bolt pattern (5 holes on a 114.3mm PCD) with conical seat M12 wheel nut holes. Design the tire bead seat with specific profiles (e.g., H2 humps). The spokes should have intricate sculpting, featuring concave and convex surfaces, and internal lightening pockets. The entire rim must exhibit a polished metallic appearance with sharp, yet filleted, edges (0.5mm to 2mm variable fillets).

Design a functional, parametrically defined compression spring. The spring should have a wire diameter of 2mm, an outer coil diameter of 20mm, and 10 active coils. The ends should be 'closed and ground', meaning the last coil at each end tapers to a flat surface perpendicular to the spring axis. The spring material should be steel. The script should allow adjustment of wire diameter, coil diameter, number of coils, and end condition type (e.g., plain, plain & ground, closed, closed & ground).

Model an intricate knurled grip for a precision tool handle. The handle base is a 25mm diameter cylinder, 100mm long. Over a 60mm length, apply a fine diamond knurling pattern with a pitch of 0.8mm and a depth of 0.3mm. The ends of the knurled section should transition smoothly (e.g., using a 2mm fillet) into the un-knurled cylindrical sections. At one end, add an M6 internal thread, 15mm deep. At the other end, add a hemispherical dome. The knurling pattern needs to be geometrically accurate for CNC machining or 3D printing.

Create a fully functional butterfly valve body. The main body is a cylinder, 150mm long, 100mm outer diameter, with an 80mm inner diameter. It must include two integrated flanges, one at each end, with 120mm outer diameter and four 12mm bolt holes on a 100mm PCD. Inside the main bore, design the pivot mechanism for the butterfly disc: two opposing 10mm diameter circular cutouts for the shaft, and a precisely sized slot (e.g., 5mm wide, 70mm long) to house the disc when closed. The internal walls should be smooth to minimize flow resistance. All transitions, especially where flanges meet the body and internal features, require 2mm fillets.

Design a complex robotic gripper finger. This single finger is 100mm long and comprises multiple articulated sections. The base section is 40mm long, attaches to a robotic arm (e.g., with a 30x20mm mounting block and two M5 holes). It then branches into two segments, each 30mm long, articulated by a custom pin joint (6mm diameter pins, 1mm clearance). Each segment should have a gripping surface with a series of parallel, 2mm deep, 2mm wide V-grooves for enhanced grip. The end of each segment should be rounded. Internal channels for pneumatic lines (3mm diameter) should run through the base and into the first segments. All external edges should have a 1mm fillet, and the articulated parts should be designed with appropriate clearances for free movement.

Design a 'Mounting Plate' for an electronic component. It should be a rectangular plate, 100mm long, 60mm wide, and 3mm thick, made from aluminum. Add four mounting holes, each 4mm in diameter, centered 10mm from each corner along the length and width axes. All sharp edges should have a 0.5mm fillet for safety and aesthetics. The surface should have a brushed finish.

Create a 'Simple Enclosure Base' for a small sensor. This part should be a box-like structure with external dimensions 50mm x 50mm x 25mm high, made of ABS plastic. It needs a wall thickness of 2mm and an open top. Include four cylindrical standoffs, 5mm diameter and 10mm tall, located at each internal corner, inset 5mm from the inner walls, to support a PCB. The base should be black with a matte finish.

Model a 'Stepped Shaft'. It consists of three cylindrical sections. The first section is 20mm diameter, 40mm long. The second section is 15mm diameter, 30mm long. The third section is 10mm diameter, 20mm long. All steps should transition smoothly with a 0.2mm chamfer. The material is stainless steel, polished finish.

Develop an 'L-Bracket with Gusset'. The main arms are 50mm long, 20mm wide, and 3mm thick, forming a 90-degree angle. Add a triangular gusset in the corner for strength, with its base along each arm, 15mm long, and 3mm thick. Include two 5mm diameter mounting holes on each arm, centered 10mm from the end and 10mm from the edge. The material is mild steel, painted black.

Construct a 'Hex Nut (M8 compatible)'. This requires a standard M8 hex nut geometry. The nominal outer flat-to-flat distance is 13mm, and the height is 6.5mm. The internal thread should be an M8x1.25 metric coarse thread (simplified representation, e.g., a simple bore of 6.8mm, but acknowledge the thread intent). Apply a 0.5mm chamfer on both top and bottom outer edges. Material: galvanized steel.

Generate a 'Simple Spacer'. It's a cylindrical body, 25mm in outer diameter, 10mm high, with a 10.5mm through-hole for a bolt (to accommodate an M10 bolt with clearance). The top and bottom outer edges should have a 1mm fillet. Material: nylon, natural color.

Design a 'Keywayed Shaft Section'. This is a cylinder 30mm in diameter and 60mm long. On one end, create a keyway: a rectangular slot, 4mm wide and 2.5mm deep, extending 25mm along the shaft's length from one end, centered on the shaft's radius. The material is hardened steel, dark grey appearance.

Create a 'Ventilation Grille Block'. Start with a rectangular block, 80mm x 40mm x 5mm thick. Cut a grid of 2mm wide rectangular slots, spaced 3mm apart, across the entire 80x40mm face. The slots should be parallel to the 40mm side and go through the 5mm thickness. Ensure a 5mm solid border around the grille. Material: white plastic.

Model a 'Threaded Cap' for a 20mm outer diameter pipe. The cap should have an external diameter of 25mm and a height of 15mm. The internal feature needs to be a simplified M20x1.5 internal thread (a bore of 18.5mm is sufficient, but visualize it as a threaded feature). Add knurling to the outer cylindrical surface (represent as a textured surface or small patterned indentations). Material: brass, polished.

Design a 'Simple Casing Cover'. This is a flat rectangular plate, 120mm x 80mm, 2mm thick. It has a central rectangular cutout, 60mm x 30mm. At each of the four corners, 7mm from the edges, include a 3mm diameter countersunk hole for M3 screws (standard 82-degree countersink). Material: brushed aluminum, 0.1mm positional accuracy for holes.

Generate a 'Parametric Involute Spur Gear'. The gear should have 24 teeth, a module of 2mm, and a pressure angle of 20 degrees. The face width should be 10mm. Include a central bore of 10mm diameter and a 4mm wide, 2mm deep keyway. All sharp edges should have a 0.2mm fillet. The gear should be made of acetal plastic, natural white color. The tooth profile must be accurately generated.

Develop a 'Helical Coil Spring'. The spring should have an outer diameter of 20mm, wire diameter of 2mm, and 8 active coils. The free length should be 40mm. Both ends should be closed and ground flat. The material is spring steel, with a metallic grey appearance. The helix must be precisely modeled.

Design a 'Curved Ergonomic Handle'. Start with a D-shaped profile (flat on one side, curved on the other) of 30mm width and 25mm height. Sweep this profile along a smooth, arc-shaped path of radius 150mm, spanning 90 degrees. Incorporate three shallow finger grooves along the underside of the handle. The handle should have an overall length of approximately 200mm. Material: rubberized plastic, black, soft-touch texture.

Model a 'Bottle Neck and Cap Assembly'. The bottle neck should have an outer diameter of 30mm, a wall thickness of 2mm, and be 25mm tall. It requires an external M28x3.0 buttress thread, 15mm long. Generate a functional spur gear. The gear should have 30 teeth, a module of 2mm, a pressure angle of 20 degrees, and a face width of 15mm.
