All internal channels must be smooth, avoid sharp corners (use fillets/blends with 2mm radius), and maintain a minimum wall thickness of 3mm to the exterior and between channels. The manifold block itself is 150mm x 100mm x 50mm. Include various M6 threaded mounting holes (4 corners, 15mm from edges) and external ports. Spatial accuracy to 0.05mm. Visual appearance: intricate internal network, uniform wall thickness, clearly defined ports and mounting points. This is a single part with highly complex internal geometry.

Create a miniature planetary gear set. This includes a sun gear, three planet gears, and a ring gear, all with a module of 1mm and a pressure angle of 20 degrees. The sun gear should have 20 teeth, the planet gears 15 teeth each, and the ring gear (internal teeth) 50 teeth. Design the carrier assembly that holds the planet gears, ensuring proper spacing and rotation with 0.1mm clearance for planet shafts. The gears and carrier should be accurate and functional for an assembly animation. All components must fit precisely. Spatial accuracy to 0.01mm for tooth profiles and clearances. Visual appearance: functional, precise gear set. This consists of multiple parts (sun, planets x3, ring, carrier) in an assembly.

Design a custom enclosure for a single-board computer (e.g., Raspberry Pi 4, 85mm x 56mm). The enclosure should have precise cutouts for all ports (USB, Ethernet, HDMI, power, audio, GPIO header). It needs a top and bottom part that snap together or are secured with small M2 screws (4 total). Include internal standoffs for mounting the PCB, and ventilation slots (e.g., 5x20mm slits) on the top. The overall aesthetics should be sleek, with filleted external edges (2mm radius) and a matte finish appearance. Spatial accuracy to 0.05mm for port cutouts and mounting features. Visual appearance: functional, aesthetically pleasing enclosure with fine details. This consists of two parts (top, bottom) in an assembly.

Model a complex aerodynamic wing profile (e.g., NACA 2412). The wing should have a chord length of 100mm at the root and taper to 70mm at the tip, over a span of 500mm. It needs to taper in both chord and thickness along the span, and have a slight dihedral angle of 5 degrees. The trailing edge should be sharp (0.5mm thickness). Integrate mounting points for a wing spar (e.g., a 10x5mm rectangular slot) at 25% chord, 100mm and 400mm from the root. Spatial accuracy to 0.01mm for airfoil shape definition. Visual appearance: smooth, continuous aerodynamic surface, precise tapering. This is a single part.

Generate a fully parametric toggle clamp mechanism, consisting of base, handle, two linkage arms, and clamp arm. All pivot points must be defined by appropriate bores (e.g., 5mm diameter) and clearances (0.1mm) for pins (not included). The mechanism should be designed to achieve a clamping force at a specific point on the clamp arm when the handle is depressed. The length of arms (e.g., 50mm, 30mm) and base dimensions (e.g., 80x40mm) should be adjustable parameters. Show the mechanism in its closed/clamped position. Spatial accuracy to 0.05mm. Visual appearance: functional, articulating mechanism. This consists of multiple parts (base, handle, 2 linkage arms, clamp arm) in an assembly.

Design a custom optical lens housing. The housing should accommodate a 25mm diameter, 5mm thick biconvex lens, held by a screw-in retainer ring (separate part) with M28x0.5 internal thread. The main body of the housing should have a 30mm long external M30x0.5 thread on one end for mounting, and a 20mm long internal M28x0.5 thread on the other end for accessories. Internal surfaces should include light baffles (internal rings/steps, 1mm wide, 1mm deep, spaced 5mm apart) to block stray light. Spatial accuracy to 0.01mm for lens fit, thread profiles, and baffles. Visual appearance: precisely machined housing, intricate internal features. This consists of two parts (housing, retainer ring) in an assembly.

Create a centrifugal pump impeller. This impeller should have 6 backward-curved blades. The impeller should have an eye (inlet) diameter of 40mm, an outer diameter of 100mm, and an overall height of 20mm. The blades should smoothly transition from the hub to the shroud, with a specific blade angle (e.g., 30 degrees backward at exit) and a smoothly varying profile. Include a central bore of 15mm diameter with a 5x2.5mm keyway for shaft mounting. Spatial accuracy to 0.05mm for blade surfaces and angles. Visual appearance: smooth, complex 3D curved blades, highly functional geometry. This is a single part.

Model a custom drone frame arm. The arm should be a hollow, tapered beam, transitioning from a 20mm x 20mm square cross-section at the fuselage end to a 15mm diameter circular cross-section at the motor mount end, over a length of 200mm. The wall thickness should be uniform at 1.5mm. It needs integrated wire routing channels (e.g., 4mm diameter) inside along its length and a mounting plate for a 22xx series motor on the circular end, with M3 bolt holes (16mm x 19mm pattern). Spatial accuracy to 0.05mm. Visual appearance: smooth, aerodynamic, hollow structure, precise mounting features. This is a single part.

Create a rectangular block with dimensions 100mm (length) x 50mm (width) x 30mm (height). On its top face, cut a cylindrical hole of 20mm diameter, centered, and going through the entire block. Add a 2mm fillet to all edges of the top face of the block. The material is a simple grey plastic.

Design a simple U-channel profile. Start with a base plate 80mm long, 40mm wide, and 5mm thick. Extrude two vertical walls, each 30mm high and 5mm thick, from the long edges of the base plate, extending inwards. Ensure the internal width of the channel is 30mm. All external sharp edges should have a 1mm chamfer. The channel should have a clean, industrial appearance.

Generate a cylindrical rod with a diameter of 25mm and a length of 150mm. On one end, add a hemispherical cap. On the other end, cut a flat recess of 5mm deep and 15mm diameter, centered. The rod should appear as polished steel.

Model a simple washer. It should be a flat disk with an outer diameter of 30mm, an inner diameter of 15mm, and a thickness of 2mm. The inner and outer edges should have a 0.5mm chamfer for ease of assembly. The washer should conceptually be made of rubber.
Create a square plate, 120mm x 120mm x 10mm thick. In each corner, drill a through-hole of 8mm diameter, centered 15mm from each adjacent edge. The plate should have a brushed metallic appearance.

Design a simple L-bracket. It's a flat rectangular plate 100mm x 50mm x 5mm. On one 100mm edge, extrude a perpendicular flange of 20mm height and 5mm thickness, extending along the entire 100mm length. Add a 2mm fillet at the junction of the plate and the flange. The material is aluminum (conceptually).

Model a basic conical frustum (truncated cone). The bottom base should have a diameter of 60mm, the top base a diameter of 30mm, and the height should be 45mm. This should be a solid object with smooth surfaces.

Create a simple cross-shaped profile. Each arm of the cross should be 10mm wide and 50mm long from the center, with a thickness of 5mm. The overall form should be a flat 2D profile extruded into a 3D object. All edges should be sharp.

Generate a hollow cylindrical pipe section. Outer diameter 50mm, inner diameter 40mm, and length 120mm. Both ends of the pipe should have a 1mm chamfer on both the inner and outer edges. It should look like a copper pipe.

Design a stepped shaft. Start with a cylinder of 30mm diameter and 60mm length. From one end, add a coaxial cylinder of 20mm diameter and 40mm length. From the other end of the 30mm diameter section, add a coaxial cylinder of 40mm diameter and 20mm length. The transitions between steps should be sharp and precise. The shaft should appear machined.

Design a hexagonal bolt head (M10 equivalent). Create a hexagonal prism with an across-flats dimension of 17mm and a height of 6.4mm. On the top and bottom faces, add a 45-degree chamfer of 0.5mm to the perimeter. Centered on one face, cut a cylindrical hole of 8.5mm diameter (representing a tapped hole) that goes through the entire height. The material is steel, with a slightly textured finish.

Model a bracket for a circular pipe. The main body is a rectangular block 80mm x 40mm x 10mm. On the 80mm x 10mm face, cut a semi-cylindrical groove of 25mm radius and 80mm length, centered along the length. On the opposite 80mm x 10mm face, drill two 6mm diameter mounting holes, centered 15mm from each end. All external sharp edges (except the groove) should have a 1mm fillet. The part should be robust and functional.

Create a heatsink fin array. Start with a base plate 100mm x 50mm x 3mm. On the 100mm x 50mm face, generate an array of 10 fins. Each fin should be 2mm thick, 40mm high, and 50mm long. They should be spaced 8mm apart (center-to-center). The top edge of each fin should have a 1mm radius rounded profile. The material is anodized aluminum, implying a smooth, heat-dissipating surface.

Design a quick-release lever handle. It consists of a main cylindrical shaft (10mm diameter, 30mm long) with a flat rectangular handle (80mm long, 15mm wide, 5mm thick) extending radially from one end. The handle should have a rounded end with a 7.5mm radius. The transition from the shaft to the handle should be smoothly filleted with a 3mm radius. On the other end of the shaft, add a small 4mm deep square recess (8mm side) for an actuator. The overall part should have a smooth plastic appearance.

Model a custom enclosure shell for electronics. The base is a rectangular box 150mm x 100mm x 30mm. Shell this box to a uniform wall thickness of 2mm, opening on the top face. On one 150mm side, create a rectangular cutout for a connector, 20mm wide and 15mm high, centered. On an adjacent 100mm side, create an array of 5 circular ventilation holes, 5mm diameter each, spaced 10mm apart, centered vertically. The external corners should have a 5mm fillet. The appearance should be a functional, matte grey enclosure.

Generate a simple cam profile. Begin with a circular blank of 60mm diameter and 10mm thickness. Cut a keyway slot (5mm wide, 3mm deep) at the center for a 10mm diameter shaft. Define a cam profile that starts as a circle of 20mm radius from the center and smoothly transitions to a lobe with a maximum radial distance of 28mm from the center, covering a 90-degree arc, then returns to the base circle. The profile should be continuous and smooth, suitable for mechanical operation.

Design a mounting plate with counterbored holes. The plate is 100mm x 70mm x 6mm thick. In each of the four corners, drill a through-hole for an M5 bolt, located 10mm from each edge. These holes should be counterbored: the top face has a 9mm diameter, 4mm deep counterbore, and the remaining material has a 5.5mm through-hole. The plate should have a matte black finish (conceptually), indicating a robust industrial part.

Model a T-slot profile. Create a solid extrusion 200mm long. The T-profile itself should have a base width of 20mm and height of 5mm, and a top 'head' of 30mm width and 5mm height, connected by a 10mm wide stem. Ensure the T-slot is fully defined with precise dimensions for mating parts. Add a 0.5mm fillet to all internal corners of the T-slot. The part should appear as extruded aluminum.

Create a threaded rod section. A cylindrical rod 20mm diameter, 100mm long. On one end, create an M20x2.5 (coarse pitch) external thread for 30mm length. On the other end, cut a 10mm deep internal M10x1.5 (coarse pitch) thread, centered. The threads should be modeled as accurately as possible for visualization, not necessarily for manufacturing simulation. The rod should be made of polished stainless steel.

Design a spherical joint component. Start with a sphere of 40mm diameter. Cut a flat surface on one side, 10mm deep, to create a D-shape section. On the opposite side, cut a spherical socket with a radius of 15mm and 20mm deep, precisely centered. The edge where the socket meets the sphere should be perfectly sharp. The material is hardened plastic, suggesting durability and smooth movement.

Design a complex multi-part enclosure for a small sensor, requiring precise fits and features.
**Part 1 (Base):** A rectangular box 70x50x20mm with 2mm wall thickness, open at the top. All external corners have a 3mm fillet. On one 70mm side, integrate a rectangular port 10x8mm, centered, with a 1mm draft angle tapering inwards. On the interior, create four mounting bosses in the corners, each a cylinder 5mm diameter, 8mm high, with a 3mm through-hole for an M3 screw.
**Part 2 (Lid):** A mating lid with a 2mm wall thickness, designed to snap-fit onto the base. It should have a 1mm overhang on all sides. Implement a living hinge design along one 70mm edge, allowing it to open. The snap-fit mechanism should involve small cantilever hooks (1mm wide, 3mm long, 1mm height with a 45-degree engagement angle) on the lid that engage corresponding slots on the base. The top surface of the lid should feature a recessed area (1mm deep, 50x30mm) for a label, with a 0.5mm chamfer around its perimeter. The overall appearance is injection-molded ABS plastic.

Generate a helical gear with specific parameters for a gear train.
**Gear 1 (Pinion):** 20 teeth, module 2.5, pressure angle 20 degrees, helix angle 15 degrees (right-hand), face width 25mm. It should have a central bore of 10mm diameter and a 4mm wide, 2mm deep keyway.
**Gear 2 (Wheel):** 40 teeth, module 2.5, pressure angle 20 degrees, helix angle 15 degrees (left-hand), face width 25mm. It should have a central bore of 20mm diameter.
Both gears should be modeled with accurate involute tooth profiles, including root and tip diameters (assume standard addendum/dedendum for simplicity). The tooth surfaces should be smooth and precise for meshing. Material is brass.

Design a complex fluid manifold block.
**Block:** A main rectangular block 150x80x40mm.
**Inlets/Outlets:** Four cylindrical ports, each 15mm diameter, positioned on the 150x40mm faces. Two on one face (20mm from top/bottom, 25mm from each end) and two on the opposite face (mirrored positions). These ports should extend 10mm outwards.
**Internal Channels:** Design a network of internal fluid channels. Channel 1 connects the top-left inlet to the bottom-right outlet diagonally through the block's interior. Channel 2 connects the top-right inlet to the bottom-left outlet. These channels should be cylindrical with 8mm diameter. Ensure channels do not intersect unless designed to do so for mixing/splitting (in this case, assume no intersection). All channels must be smoothly blended.
**Mounting:** Four through-holes for M6 bolts, 10mm from each corner on the 150x80mm top face, with a 1mm chamfer on the hole edges.
**Material:** Stainless steel, with highly polished internal channels for minimal flow resistance.

Model a turbine blade.
**Blade Profile:** Define an intricate airfoil profile (e.g., using a complex spline-based curve for leading and trailing edges) on a base plane.
**Root:** Transition this profile into a fir-tree root attachment geometry (three symmetrical 'fingers' for mounting into a disk) at one end, over a length of 20mm.
**Tip:** The blade extends 80mm from the root. As it extends, the airfoil profile should smoothly twist by 20 degrees and scale down uniformly by 10% in chord length. The blade should maintain a constant thickness-to-chord ratio along its length.
**Fillets:** Add a 1mm fillet where the blade meets the root. The surface should be extremely smooth, reflecting a polished superalloy material suitable for high-speed aerodynamics.

Create a complex parametric joint component (e.g., a universal joint yoke).
**Part 1 (Yoke):** A U-shaped component with an overall length of 80mm, width 40mm, and height 30mm. The arms of the 'U' are 10mm thick, and the base is 10mm thick. Each arm has a through-hole of 12mm diameter, coaxial, for a pin. The ends of the arms are rounded with a 5mm radius.
**Part 2 (Cross/Pin):** A central cross-shaped pin assembly. The main pin is 12mm diameter, 50mm long, designed to fit through the yoke. Perpendicular to this, another pin of 10mm diameter, 40mm long, passes through the center. This second pin has a spherical boss (20mm diameter) at its center, with the 10mm pin passing through it.
The goal is for Part 1 to articulate freely around Part 2's main pin, and Part 2's second pin to allow for rotation within another component (not modeled). Ensure precise clearances for movement (0.1mm clearance on all mating surfaces). All surfaces should be smooth and appear to be of hardened steel.

Design a custom PCB housing with internal standoffs and cable management.
**Housing Body:** A rectangular box 120x80x30mm with 1.5mm wall thickness, open at the top. All external edges have a 2mm fillet.
**Internal Standoffs:** Four cylindrical standoffs, 5mm diameter, 10mm high, with a 3mm through-hole, located 10mm from each corner on the internal floor, for mounting a 100x60mm PCB.
**Cable Routing:** Integrate a cable channel (5x5mm square profile) along one 120mm side, internally, running the full length, with an exit port on one of the 80mm faces.
**Ventilation:** On the 120x80mm bottom face, create a grid of 20 uniformly spaced 3mm diameter holes for ventilation, maintaining a minimum 3mm distance from edges and standoffs.
**Mounting Tabs:** On the exterior of the two 80mm sides, create two mounting tabs (15mm wide, 10mm high, 3mm thick) with a 6mm through-hole, located centrally.
**Material:** Semi-transparent plastic, allowing internal components to be dimly visible.

Create a complex surface geometry: a 'parametric wavy grid'.
**Base Surface:** Start with a flat square surface 100x100mm.
**Wave Pattern:** Impose a sinusoidal wave pattern across this surface in both X and Y directions. The wave amplitude should be 5mm, and the wavelength 25mm in both directions. This should create a smoothly undulating surface.
**Grid Cutout:** On this wavy surface, cut a grid of square holes. Each hole should be 3mm x 3mm, spaced 5mm apart (center-to-center). The grid should cover the entire 100x100mm area, conforming to the wavy surface. The remaining material should be 2mm thick, following the wavy contours.
**Frame:** Surround this wavy grid with a 5mm thick, 10mm wide frame. The frame should follow the external contours of the grid and be flush with its top surface.
**Material:** An aesthetically pleasing, polished chrome effect, emphasizing the complex surface.

Design an intricate interlocking puzzle piece.
**Overall Form:** A 60x60x15mm cube.
**Interlocking Features:** On each face, create a unique, non-planar interlocking profile (e.g., a combination of a dovetail, a T-slot, and a complex S-curve). Each profile should be precisely defined so that it can only mate with a specific complementary piece (which is not modeled here but implicitly defined by the cuts). These features should extend fully across each face.
**Internal Void:** Create an internal spherical void of 20mm diameter, centered within the cube.
**Aesthetics:** The piece should appear to be made from a dense, smooth wood. Ensure all mating surfaces are precisely perpendicular or parallel where intended, with zero clearance for a snug fit, indicating a perfectly machined puzzle.

Model a complex custom bottle opener with ergonomic grip.
**Main Body:** Start with a base shape that is a combination of a flat plate and an ergonomic curve. The handle should be approximately 120mm long, 30mm wide at its widest, and 10mm thick. It should have a subtle S-curve profile along its length for comfortable gripping.
**Opener Head:** At one end, integrate the bottle opener mechanism: a circular cutout (25mm diameter) with a small cantilever hook (3mm thick, 5mm projection) to engage bottle caps. The hook should have a sharp, precise engagement edge.
**Finger Grooves:** Along the underside of the handle, carve out two ergonomic finger grooves, each 5mm deep and smoothly curved for a comfortable grip.
**Lanyard Hole:** At the opposite end of the handle, include a 5mm diameter lanyard hole, smoothly chamfered on both sides.
**Visual:** The design should look like a sleek, injection-molded plastic product with a soft-touch texture.

Generate a suspension arm component for a small robot.
**Main Arm:** A tapering beam structure. It starts with a rectangular cross-section of 20x15mm at one end, tapering down to 10x8mm over a length of 100mm. It should have a slight downward curve along its length (e.g., a 5mm sag over 100mm).
**Mounting Point 1 (Chassis):** At the wider end, create a clevis joint: two parallel plates, each 5mm thick, 20mm high, spaced 10mm apart, with a 8mm diameter through-hole coaxial in both plates, for a pivot pin. The plates should extend 15mm from the end of the arm.
**Mounting Point 2 (Wheel):** At the narrower end, create a spherical bearing housing: a cylindrical bore of 15mm diameter, 15mm deep, with a spherical seat of 7.5mm radius at its base. The end of the arm should fully encapsulate this housing.
**Weight Reduction:** Implement a series of 5 elliptical cutouts (10x5mm, 3mm deep) along the center of the arm, evenly spaced, to reduce weight, while maintaining structural integrity.
**Material:** High-strength aluminum, with a clear anodized finish, indicating a performance-oriented part.

Create a rectangular block with dimensions 100mm length, 50mm width, and 20mm height. On its top face, cut a cylindrical hole with a diameter of 15mm, centered 25mm from one short edge and 25mm from one long edge. All edges of the block should have a 2mm fillet, and the rim of the cylindrical hole should have a 1mm chamfer. The final part should have a smooth, anodized aluminum appearance.

Design a simple U-bracket. Start with a base plate 80mm long, 40mm wide, and 5mm thick. From the 80mm edges, extrude two walls upwards by 30mm. These walls should be 5mm thick. The inner radius of the bend between the base and the walls should be 2mm. On the center of each of the two vertical walls, drill a through-hole with a diameter of 8mm, positioned 15mm from the top edge. The bracket should appear as a painted black steel component.

Model a hexagonal bolt head with a thickness of 10mm. The distance across the flats should be 20mm. On its top surface, cut a circular recess for a washer seat, 18mm in diameter and 1mm deep, centered with the hexagon. In the very center, drill a through-hole with a diameter of 10mm. The part should have a machined steel finish.

Generate a cylindrical shaft with a total length of 150mm and a diameter of 20mm. At one end, reduce the diameter to 15mm for a length of 30mm, creating a shoulder. At the opposite end, create a 45-degree chamfer with a 2mm distance from the end face. On the 20mm diameter section, drill three through-holes of 5mm diameter, equally spaced around the circumference and 50mm from the unchamfered end. The shaft should have a polished stainless steel appearance.

Construct a truncated cone. The base should be a circle with a diameter of 60mm, and the top face a circle with a diameter of 30mm. The total height of the truncated cone is 50mm. Shell the cone with an internal wall thickness of 2mm, leaving the base open. The part should have a smooth ceramic look.

Model a simple pipe elbow. It should be a 90-degree bend with a centerline radius of 50mm. The pipe itself has an outer diameter of 30mm and an inner diameter of 25mm. Ensure a smooth transition through the bend. The pipe should have a rustic cast iron texture.

Create a rectangular plate with dimensions 200mm x 100mm x 5mm. On this plate, create a linear array of 5mm diameter through-holes. There should be 5 holes along the 200mm length, spaced 40mm apart, and 3 holes along the 100mm width, spaced 30mm apart. The holes should start 20mm from each edge. The plate should be made of clear acrylic.

Design a simple lever arm. It consists of a rectangular main body 150mm long, 20mm wide, and 10mm thick. At one end, extend a circular boss with a diameter of 30mm and 10mm length, centered with the arm's width, which has a 12mm through-hole. At the other end, create a smaller circular boss with a diameter of 25mm and 10mm length, also centered, with an 8mm through-hole. All sharp edges should have a 1mm fillet. The lever should appear as a brushed aluminum component.

Model a dovetail joint, specifically a single male pin. The main block is 50mm x 50mm x 20mm. On one 50x50 face, extrude a trapezoidal pin with a base width of 30mm, a top width of 20mm, and a height of 15mm. The pin should be centered on the face. The angles of the dovetail sides should be 10 degrees from the vertical. The part should have a natural wood finish.

Construct a basic support foot. It has a circular base with a diameter of 60mm and a height of 10mm. On top of this, a smaller cylinder, 40mm in diameter and 30mm high, is centered. On the top face of the smaller cylinder, cut a circular recess 30mm in diameter and 5mm deep. In the center of this recess, drill a 6mm diameter through-hole. The entire part should have a smooth, dark grey rubber appearance.

Create a simple box with an open top. The outer dimensions are 70mm length, 40mm width, and 30mm height. The wall thickness should be uniform at 3mm. All outer vertical edges should have a 1mm fillet. The box should appear as a smooth, translucent blue plastic.

Design an involute spur gear with the following specifications: 30 teeth, a module of 2mm, pressure angle of 20 degrees, and a face width of 15mm. The bore should be 10mm with a 3mm wide keyway. All sharp edges of the gear teeth should have a small 0.5mm chamfer for deburring. The gear should have a hardened steel appearance with visible tooth profiles.

Model a custom threaded M16 bolt, 80mm long, with a standard ISO metric coarse pitch (2.0mm). The bolt head should be a standard M16 hex head with a 24mm across-flats dimension and 10mm height. Below the head, add a 2mm thick washer face with a diameter of 28mm. Simulate the helical thread profile accurately along the bolt's shank for 60mm, ensuring correct thread depth. The part should exhibit a raw, machined steel aesthetic.

Create a shelled enclosure for a small electronic device. The outer dimensions are 120mm long, 70mm wide, and 30mm high. It should have a uniform wall thickness of 1.5mm. On one of the 70x30mm end faces, cut out a rectangular opening 20mm x 10mm, centered. On the opposite end, create four mounting bosses, 10mm diameter and 10mm high, with a 3mm through-hole, positioned 10mm from each corner of the end face (measured to boss center). The enclosure should have a smooth, injection-molded ABS plastic finish, dark grey.

Design a complex cam profile for a follower. The cam should have an outer diameter of 80mm, an inner bore of 15mm, and a thickness of 10mm. The profile should provide a specific motion:
1. Dwell for 60 degrees.
2. Rise 10mm over 90 degrees with constant velocity.
3. Dwell for 30 degrees.
4. Fall 10mm over 120 degrees with constant velocity.
5. Return to start over the remaining 60 degrees (if not already there).
Assume a roller follower with a diameter of 10mm for profile generation. The cam should have a polished tool steel appearance.

Model a flexible coupling hub. It has an outer diameter of 50mm, an inner bore of 20mm, and a length of 40mm. Around its circumference, create six radially oriented slots, each 8mm wide and extending 15mm from the outer surface, forming a 'jaw' type coupling. These slots should be evenly spaced. All internal and external corners should have a 1mm fillet. The part should be imagined as a durable, precision-machined aluminum component.

Create a helical compression spring. The wire diameter is 2mm. The mean coil diameter is 20mm. The spring should have 10 active coils, with squared and ground ends. The free length of the spring is 40mm. The spring should appear as shiny spring steel. Ensure accurate helical path generation and wire profile sweep.

Design a custom heatsink profile. Start with a base plate 100mm x 100mm x 5mm. On top of this, extrude 10 fins, each 95mm long, 2mm thick, and 30mm high. The fins should be uniformly spaced with 8mm gaps between them, starting 2.5mm from one edge and centered on the plate. All fin edges should have a 0.5mm chamfer. The heatsink should have a dull, extruded aluminum finish.

Model a two-part snap-fit enclosure.
Part 1 (Base): Rectangular box, outer dimensions 100x60x20mm, wall thickness 2mm. Bottom is solid. The top edge features four snap-fit hooks on the long sides, each 5mm wide, 3mm deep, and positioned 10mm from each corner.
Part 2 (Lid): Rectangular lid, outer dimensions 100x60x5mm, wall thickness 2mm. Its inner profile should precisely match the outer profile of the base, allowing for a 0.1mm clearance fit. The lid should have corresponding snap-fit recesses that mate with the hooks on the base.
Both parts should have a matte white plastic appearance. Focus on precise clearance for the snap-fit.

Create a T-slot profile rail, 300mm long. The T-slot profile should be such that the top part of the 'T' is 20mm wide and 5mm thick. The vertical stem of the 'T' is 10mm wide and 15mm tall. The bottom base of the 'T' (which would typically bolt to another surface) is 30mm wide and 8mm thick. The overall height is 28mm. All internal corners of the slot should have a 1mm fillet. The rail should appear as anodized structural aluminum.

Design a detailed electrical connector body. It's a rectangular block, 40mm long, 20mm wide, and 15mm high. On one 20x15mm face, create an array of 12 circular pin holes, 1.5mm diameter, arranged in a 3x4 grid with 4mm spacing between centers in both directions, and a 5mm margin from the edges. The holes should go through 10mm of the block. On the opposite face, add a 10mm long cable strain relief feature, which is a rounded rectangular protrusion 15mm wide and 8mm high, hollowed out to match the internal pin pathways. The body should be made of a rigid, grey plastic.

Model a mounting bracket for a cylindrical object. The bracket should consist of a flat base plate, 100mm long, 40mm wide, and 5mm thick. From the long edges of this base, two semicircular 'arms' extend upwards by 50mm, forming a cradle for a 30mm diameter cylinder. These arms should also be 5mm thick. At the base of each arm, a 10mm diameter counterbore hole (15mm diameter, 8mm deep) is required, centered 15mm from the short edges. The bracket should have a matte black powder-coated steel finish.

Design a custom, organically shaped phone stand. The base should be roughly 100mm long and 80mm wide, with a height that gradually rises from 10mm at the front to 40mm at the back. It should have a curved recess to hold a phone, approximately 15mm deep and 12mm wide, running across the top surface. Include a cable pass-through hole, 10mm diameter, at the base of this recess. The overall shape should be smooth and flowing. The stand should appear as a high-quality, polished solid wood block.

Model a miniature planetary gear set.
1.  **Sun Gear:** 20 teeth, module 1.5mm, 10mm face width, 5mm bore.
2.  **Planet Gear (3 identical):** 15 teeth, module 1.5mm, 10mm face width, 5mm bore. Ensure these mesh correctly with the sun gear.
3.  **Ring Gear:** Internally toothed, 50 teeth, module 1.5mm, 10mm face width. This should precisely mesh with the planet gears.
4.  **Carrier Plate:** A circular plate that holds the planet gears, ensuring they are correctly spaced and constrained. It should have three posts for the planet gears, and a central bore for the sun gear shaft.
Ensure all gears have a 20-degree pressure angle. All meshing clearances must be precisely accounted for (e.g., 0.05mm backlash if desired). The assembly should appear as highly polished brass components.

Design a Geneva Drive mechanism, consisting of two main parts:
1.  **Drive Wheel:** A circular disc with a diameter of 100mm and a thickness of 10mm. It features a single driving pin, 8mm in diameter and 15mm long, positioned 35mm from the center. It also has a circular blocking segment on its circumference to lock the driven wheel during dwell periods.
2.  **Driven Wheel (4-slot):** A circular disc with a diameter of 100mm and a thickness of 10mm. It contains four precision-machined slots for the driving pin, angled to allow smooth entry and exit. The slots should allow for the 8mm pin to pass through with a 0.1mm clearance. A central bore of 15mm is required.
Ensure precise kinematic clearances for smooth operation. The parts should be depicted as high-precision, hardened steel components, with distinct color for each part (e.g., blue drive, red driven).

Model a complex, double-curved turbine impeller blade. The blade should sweep from a central hub (50mm diameter) outwards to an outer shroud (150mm diameter). The blade's profile must smoothly transition from an airfoil-like shape at its root to a different airfoil-like shape at its tip, incorporating a significant and continuous twist along its height (e.g., 60 degrees). This requires multiple complex guide curves and profiles for advanced lofting or sweeping operations to capture the aerodynamic shape.

Design an assembly consisting of a cylindrical housing (50mm outer diameter, 40mm inner diameter, 100mm long), a plunger (38mm outer diameter, 80mm long) that slides precisely within the housing, and a conical compression spring. The spring should be parametrically modeled (e.g., 2mm wire diameter, 30mm large coil diameter tapering to 15mm small coil diameter, 10 active coils, 60mm free length). Position the spring between the base of the housing and the plunger, showing it compressed by 10mm, ensuring correct physical interaction and assembly.

Design an ergonomic handle grip for a tool. The grip should be organically curved, approximately 150mm long. It needs distinct finger grooves, a palm swell for comfort, and a textured surface (e.g., a repeating hexagonal or diamond pattern, recessed by 0.5mm, covering the gripping areas). The overall form should be developed using multiple lofts, sweeps, and blend surfaces to achieve a natural, hand-conforming shape.

Design a complete planetary gear set. This includes a central sun gear (e.g., 20 teeth), three planet gears (e.g., 15 teeth each), and an outer ring gear (e.g., 50 teeth, internal teeth). All gears must have accurate involute profiles and be parametrically linked to a module (e.g., 2mm) and number of teeth. Model the planet carrier and fixed shafts/bearings necessary for the assembly, demonstrating correct meshing, spacing, and functional rotation.

Redesign an L-bracket (based on intermediate prompt #5: 100x75x50x5mm) for lightweighting. The outer dimensions, mounting hole positions (two 8mm holes on each leg, 15mm from edges), and overall functionality must remain identical. However, hollow out the internal structure and replace it with a diamond or honeycomb lattice pattern (e.g., 5mm cell size, 1mm wall thickness) to optimize for strength-to-weight ratio. The lattice should be smoothly integrated with the external walls.

Design a custom enclosure for an electronic device, composed of two mating halves (top and bottom). The overall external dimensions should be approximately 120mm x 80mm x 40mm. The top surface should be gently curved. Include a rectangular recess for an LCD screen (e.g., 60x30mm) and four circular recesses for buttons (e.g., 10mm diameter), possibly with undercuts for flush-fitting components. Inside, include four cylindrical mounting bosses (e.g., 8mm diameter, 10mm height, with 3mm holes) for a PCB. The two halves should mate perfectly with a tongue-and-groove or labyrinth-style sealing mechanism.

Model a single segment of a small articulated robot arm. This involves a main arm link (e.g., a complex shape with internal cavities for weight reduction, length 150mm). At one end, design a 'fork' or 'clevis' type joint (e.g., 30mm wide gap, 10mm pin hole) with integrated bearing seats. At the other end, model a mounting interface for a motor/gearbox (e.g., a flange with bolt holes). Include features like internal cable routing channels (e.g., 5x5mm square channel) that run the length of the segment. Emphasize precise alignment, smooth transitions, and manufacturability considerations.

Design a fluidic connector assembly consisting of two mating halves. Each half needs an external threaded connection (e.g., G1/4 BSPP parallel pipe thread) on one side. On the mating face, design internal S-shaped or curved channels (e.g., 2mm diameter) that align perfectly and create a continuous, smooth fluid path when the two halves are assembled. The internal channels must be free of sharp corners or abrupt changes in cross-section to ensure efficient fluid flow.

Design a repetitive architectural façade element, approximately 1 meter x 1 meter square. This element should feature a complex, non-rectangular pattern of through-cutouts or protrusions. For example, implement a Voronoi pattern, a tessellation of irregular polygons, or an organic branching structure. The pattern should be applied to a 10mm thick base panel, creating depth and visual interest suitable for a modern building façade. The pattern should be generated parametrically to allow for variations in density or complexity.
Create a solid cube with side length 50mm. Accurately center a through-hole of 10mm diameter on one face, extending completely through to the opposite face. All edges should be sharp.
Design a solid cylinder with a diameter of 30mm and a height of 45mm. Apply a 2mm x 45-degree chamfer to the top circular edge. The bottom edge should remain sharp.

Generate a rectangular plate of 100mm length, 60mm width, and 5mm thickness. Add four equally spaced through-holes of 5mm diameter, positioned 10mm from each corner along the length and width axes. All edges should be sharp.
Model a circular washer with an outer diameter of 25mm, an inner diameter of 10mm, and a thickness of 2mm. Ensure perfect concentricity between the inner and outer circles. Edges should be crisp.
Construct a rectangular base with dimensions 80mm x 40mm and a height of 10mm. Apply a uniform fillet of 5mm radius to all four vertical edges. The top and bottom faces should be flat.

Create a hexagonal bolt head. The distance across the flats should be 13mm, and the height of the head should be 8mm. The top edges of the hexagon should have a small chamfer of 0.5mm x 45 degrees for aesthetic finish.

Design an L-bracket from a 3mm thick material. One arm should be 50mm long and 30mm wide, and the other arm should be 40mm long and 30mm wide. Ensure the corner where the two arms meet is a clean, sharp 90-degree internal angle. No holes are required.

Model a circular disk with a 60mm diameter and 5mm thickness. Create a central through-hole of 8mm diameter. Additionally, add two offset through-holes of 4mm diameter, positioned 20mm from the center, diametrically opposite each other. All holes should be perfectly aligned and symmetrical.

Generate a spherical cap. Start with a sphere of 40mm radius. Then, cut off the top portion such that the resulting cap has a height of 15mm from its base. The base of the cap should be perfectly flat.

Construct a 150mm long T-profile beam. The top flange should be 40mm wide and 5mm thick. The web extending downwards from the center of the flange should be 50mm high and 5mm thick. All intersections should be sharp 90-degree angles.

Develop a single parametric spur gear. The gear should have 20 teeth, a module of 2mm, a pressure angle of 20 degrees, and a face width of 10mm. Include a central bore of 10mm diameter and a 3mm wide keyway. All tooth profiles must be accurately generated using involute curves. The gear should be free of burrs and have a smooth finish.

Model a 50mm long threaded rod with M12x1.75 metric coarse threads. Also, design a hexagonal nut (distance across flats 19mm, height 10mm) that accurately mates with this thread. The nut should have a chamfer on both top and bottom outer edges. The thread profile must be precise to allow for a smooth fit between the rod and nut.

Create a cylindrical handle section, 25mm in diameter and 70mm long. Apply a straight knurl pattern to the outer surface with a pitch of 1mm and a depth of 0.5mm. The knurl should provide a distinct, grippable texture. The ends of the handle should be smoothly rounded with a 3mm radius.

Design a V-belt pulley with an outer diameter of 80mm, a total width of 25mm. It should feature a standard V-groove for a Type A belt (34-degree groove angle, 13mm top width, 8mm depth). Include a central bore of 15mm diameter and two lightweighting holes (e.g., 20mm diameter) positioned concentrically around the central bore. All edges should be clean, with minor fillets (0.5mm) on the groove corners.

Model a 100mm long pipe section with an inner diameter of 50mm and a wall thickness of 5mm. Both ends should feature a circular flange, 100mm outer diameter and 10mm thick. Each flange should have four symmetrically placed through-holes of 12mm diameter for mounting. Fillet the internal and external corners where the pipe meets the flange with a 2mm radius.

Design a housing for a standard 6203 ball bearing (OD 40mm, ID 17mm, Width 12mm). The housing should be a rectangular block 60mm x 50mm x 30mm. It needs a central bore to precisely fit the bearing's outer diameter, with a 0.1mm interference fit. Include four mounting holes of 6mm diameter, located 10mm from each corner on the base. A small 1mm chamfer on the bearing bore entry for ease of assembly.

Create a simplified propeller blade. Start with a central hub cylinder of 20mm diameter and 15mm height. From this hub, generate a single blade that extends 60mm outwards. The blade should start with a root profile (e.g., 10mm wide, 3mm thick elliptical section) and transition to a tip profile (e.g., 5mm wide, 1mm thick elliptical section) with a 15-degree twist along its length. Use a loft or sweep operation for the blade geometry. The connection to the hub should be smooth.

Model a male dovetail component and a corresponding female dovetail slot component. Each piece should be 100mm long, 30mm wide. The dovetail angle should be 14 degrees, with a base width of 20mm for the male part. The female part must be precisely cut to accept the male part with a snug fit. Both components should have a thickness of 15mm.

Design a clevis pin. The main body should be a cylinder 10mm diameter and 50mm long. It requires a through-hole for a cotter pin, 2mm diameter, located 5mm from one end. At the other end, create a longitudinal slot, 2mm wide and 15mm deep, extending from the end face into the pin, centered on the diameter. Both ends of the pin should have a 1mm chamfer.

Create a control knob with a star-shaped grip. Start with a cylindrical base of 30mm diameter and 10mm height. On top, extrude a star with 5 points, where the outer points are on a 40mm diameter circle and the inner points are on a 20mm diameter circle, extruded to a height of 15mm. The knob should have a central D-shaft bore (6mm diameter, flat on one side for 5mm) through its entire height. All exterior edges of the star should be lightly filleted (0.5mm).

Design a complete planetary gear set assembly consisting of a Sun Gear, three Planet Gears, a Ring Gear, and a Planet Carrier. All gears should have a module of 1.5mm and a pressure angle of 20 degrees. The Sun Gear should have 20 teeth, and the Planet Gears 15 teeth. The Ring Gear must accurately mesh with the Planet Gears. The Planet Carrier needs pivot pins for the Planet Gears and a central shaft interface for the Sun Gear. Ensure all gears mesh correctly, and the assembly is dynamically functional (conceptually). Define all tooth profiles using precise involute curves and apply appropriate clearances (0.05mm) for smooth rotation between components. Include mounting features for the carrier and a central hub for the sun gear.

Design a two-part (top and bottom) enclosure for electronics. The overall dimensions are 120mm x 80mm x 40mm, with a uniform wall thickness of 2mm. The two halves should connect using four snap-fit latches – two on each long side – with a 0.5mm interference fit for a secure closure. Include a pattern of 10mm x 2mm rectangular ventilation slots on the top surface. The bottom half should have four integrated mounting standoffs for a PCB (5mm diameter, 10mm high, with a 3mm through-hole) and four rubber feet recesses. All external edges should have a 1mm radius fillet for ergonomics. Incorporate draft angles (1 degree) on vertical features for manufacturability.

Model a single-axis articulated joint for a small robot arm. The joint consists of three primary components: a central pivot block (50x30x20mm), and two identical 'arm' components (each 80mm long, 20mm wide, 15mm thick) that attach to either side of the pivot. The arm components should have a 'finger' design that interlocks with a central slot in the pivot block, allowing for 180 degrees of rotation. A precise 8mm diameter through-bore should align perfectly across all three parts for a pivot pin. Include features like end stops for rotation limit, and mounting holes (4x M4 threaded) on the outer faces of the arm components. Fillet all functional edges (0.5mm) for smooth operation.

Generate a turbine blade with a chord length of 50mm at the root and 30mm at the tip, and a total span of 100mm. The blade profile must transition from a NACA 4-digit airfoil (e.g., NACA 2412) at the root to a different NACA 4-digit airfoil (e.g., NACA 0009) at the tip. Additionally, the blade should have a 30-degree twist along its span and a varying thickness distribution. The leading and trailing edges must be sharply defined (0.1mm radius max). The root of the blade needs to integrate seamlessly with a circular platform (40mm diameter, 5mm thick) for mounting.

Design the top half of an ergonomic computer mouse shell. The overall footprint should be approximately 120mm long, 65mm wide, and 35mm high. The shape must be smooth, organic, and contoured to fit a hand, using multiple lofted or swept surfaces based on complex spline profiles. Include a recessed area for a scroll wheel (20mm wide) and two primary button depressions. The shell should have a uniform wall thickness of 1.5mm. All external surfaces must be flawlessly blended with continuous curvature (G2 continuity) for a premium tactile feel.

Create a high-density heat sink with dimensions 80mm x 80mm base, and 40mm total height. The base plate should be 5mm thick. From this base, generate 40 individual cooling fins, each 0.8mm thick, 35mm high, and 70mm long. The fins should be slightly curved (e.g., 5mm radius of curvature over their length) and tapered in thickness towards the top (from 0.8mm at base to 0.4mm at top). Maintain a precise spacing of 1.2mm between fins. The entire assembly should have a clean, precise, and visually appealing 'machined' finish.

Design a single blade for a centrifugal impeller. The blade should be 60mm long from the hub, 20mm wide at the inlet and 15mm wide at the outlet, and have a thickness of 2mm. The blade must have a complex 3D curvature, both radially and tangentially, such that it guides airflow effectively. The inlet angle should be 30 degrees from tangential, and the outlet angle 45 degrees from tangential. The blade needs to smoothly transition to a central hub (30mm diameter, 10mm thick) and incorporate a slight draft (0.5 degrees) for manufacturing considerations. The leading and trailing edges should be sharp (0.2mm radius).

Model a custom plastic bottle with an overall height of 150mm and a maximum diameter of 70mm at its base, tapering to a neck diameter of 25mm. The bottle's body should have an organic, smoothly curved profile (e.g., an hourglass shape or a subtle S-curve). The neck requires a custom external buttress thread (e.g., 2.5mm pitch, 30mm length). Emboss a 30mm x 15mm rectangular logo (simple text 'CQ') onto a curved surface of the bottle body with a 0.5mm height. The bottle should have a uniform wall thickness of 1.2mm and a slightly domed bottom. All external surfaces must be smooth and free of discontinuities.
